description:
Went here on a whim when I was here for a conference. The shiro wot and mesir wot were sooo flavorful. Very generous portions and gave more than enough of the delicious injera bread. 

Love these mom and pop shops, and this one certainly didn't disappoint. When I asked which one he'd recommend, he told me the shiro wot and gave me a scoop of mesir wot on the side to try. Loved this couple and wish their restaurant the best!! 

On a side note, I went by myself and got catcalled at least 5-6 times in the time that I walked the 0.2 miles from where I was. If you're with a family or it's after dark, I'd recommend grabbing a Lyft or Uber to get to the area.
author: Emily C.

description:
Found this place via Yelp. Decided to give it a try based on the high & positive ratings, and also because it was a short 7-min walk from our hotel. We got the veg combo, and let me tell you: the food was delicious! I've eaten Ethiopian food in various cities and states, and the food here is on point, if not better for some of the dishes. 

My fav item from the veg combo was the salad, alicha, and misir wot. I can eat those 3 items all day long!

The restaurant is in the Tenderloin and we walked through some very sketchy blocks and sketchy people, so be careful. If you're afraid, I'd highly recommend taking a Lyft or Uber.
author: Hanh N.

description:
Food is ABSOLUTELY delicious. Restaurant is clean and I like the size and vibe, definitely has a sweet "mom & pops" feel to it. They could do better on the servings, though. When my friend and I got 2 vegetarian combos, they combined it on one large plate for the both of us and it really wasn't enough to justify the fact that we had paid for 2 meals. The distribution was off too - one of my servings of the combo was lacking the ingredients that my friends had of the same meal. They were, however were very nice about it when I brought that up and gave me extra servings. That made my tummy very happy :) Also, most of the workers aren't fluent in English and sometimes don't understand you but usually, if there is difficulty due to the language barrier, they'll get help and make sure to meet your needs. 
Another negative experience, which is my last favorite, was that while my friend and I were eating, a server came up to us and offered us more bread. We agreed. When we got our checks it had turned out that they actually charged us for it. This was very off and unprofessional since we were offered the bread and never asked for it ourselves and none of them even once mentioned that it will be of additional charge, as if we had ordered another side of bread. But that may also be due to the fact that most of them can barely speak in English. 
I'd recommend this place because it tastes good, but some tips would be to be careful and make sure you are well understood, if anything is wrong speak up because they're pretty nice and will accommodate you, and if you order more than 1 of the same order, ask for two separate plates instead of one combined plate to make sure you get a fair size of servings.
author: Anna A.

description:
This place I definitely recommend
Beautiful simple inside with great service. As a chef who has worked at some of the Michelin restaurants in this city this place knows flavor. You won't be disappointed give Tadu a try.
author: Danny M.

description:
This place is pretty good.  My first time trying Ethiopian food. Service is good but a bit slow which its because they do get busy which I'm ok with. 4 star from me. 

Flaxseed drink with honey taste like blended peanut butter not to sweet: pretty interesting. The ground beef kitfo cooked medium rare is spicy and good. The chicken tibs is pretty good but I like dark than white. So it does cater for vegetarians and meat eaters. 

A lot of people usually get their veggie combo. Oh and the injera is like a sour dough pancake you use to wrap the food to eat with. You use your hand/fingers and injera to eat the food. 

The place is small so get there when they open or when rush hours are over. I see people usually order togo and from delivery company since the place is small. Tables I see is 4 or less but I'm sure you can squeeze the tables or chairs together for bigger parties if they aren't already filled. 

Fun experience, not everyday kind of food and pretty filling due to the injera. Definitely come again when there's parking. Parking is hard and lots of drugs,homeless and crazy people so just a heads up. Still worth to come by at lease once.
author: Christy V.

description:
This is in a tough neighborhood so be aware.  

The food was ok.  It was cooked fresh in this small five table restaurant.  There were language barriers which is fine.  It meant we did not receive our appetizer.  The food was good enough.  The flavors were nice. My favorite of the combination plate ended up being the lentils which were magically sour and good.
author: Kori H.

description:
Lovely lunch with co-workers while I was in town!
This lil spot hit the spot!
I had the Veggie Tidbits and they were fantastic! 
Wonderful plate of multiple vegan dishes with fantastic spice and a taste of freshness! 
I dug my unhealthy Fanta soda, with my healthy lunch!
Staff was really sweet and very attentive, filling waters and making sure we had everything we needed.. This is a clean cool place with great food! Dig in!
author: Patrick T.

description:
San Francisco Ethiopian food great and in the loin. Call and see if you can bring your own drinks. 
Really appreciate all the customer service provided and when she started storing the beans with a very very big stick I was like wow this is super authentic I think this restaurant deserves to be visited at least once a week to possibly ordered from home for because Ric parties I am I think they use really going for it you should really order order a lot of food here thank U thank U so good so good delicious
author: John G.

description:
Met up with some old coworkers for lunch here after one of them was recommended this place. It was my first time having Ethiopian food, but I'm definitely a fan now! 

We ordered the chicken bits, lamb and veggie platter. This was more than enough for the 3 of us. The flavors here were incredible. The lamb was my favorite! The location is small and seating can be limited if you decide to dine in. Prices here are fair and also great for take out. 

If you haven't had Ethiopian food before, I highly recommend you try it because your missing out! My only complaint about this place is the location. It is located in the tenderloin and if your a female walking alone it can be a little sketchy in areas from the nearby bart stations.
author: Lauren P.

description:
Coming here late in the evening can be dangerous since it's in the Tenderloin but trust me, the food is well worth the risk!

Had the chicken tibs and boy was it delicious! Full of flavor and they give you a side of injera to eat with as well! The spice can be adjusted with the jalapenos on the side which was a nice touch. Quick service, friendly and helpful staff, and overall great quality of food!

The only reason I gave this place 1 less star is the location. Not exactly the safest neighborhood but well worth the trouble.
author: Alan C.

description:
I ended up here after trying to go to a ramen place on Geary St where the line was too long and I didn't want to wait. 

I saw that Tadu had an excellent Yelp rating and thought that having dinner here would be a suitable backup to the ramen place. As I started to walk closer and closer to Tadu I realized that I was entering the Tenderloin since it started becoming progressively more scary as I was walking towards the restaurant.

Tadu seemed to be almost at the boundary point of the scariness, so I decided to go anyways even though it definitely crossed my mind to turn back and walk out of the neighborhood for safety reasons. 

Tadu is an extremely small restaurant, so I suppose I was lucky that I found a small table that was shoved in the corner and could barely fit me. It was definitely packed in the small restaurant, but at least there wasn't a wait when I arrived. 

I ordered the vegetarian combo (vegan) which was enough food to be filling without having enough for leftovers. Which I guess is the perfect size especially if you are traveling. It tasted really good and the food itself was 4 stars. The injera tasted a little too sour for my taste, but everything else was definitely tasty.  Environment does matter a ton to me though, so being shoved in the corner in a scary neighborhood is enough to make me not want to return. 

After I sat down, there started to be a line about 10 minutes later in front of the restaurant and I thought to myself how if there was a line when I arrived I definitely would not have eaten here. 

I don't regret eating here last night but am reminded why The Tenderloin is a neighborhood that is best avoided if possible.
author: Regina W.

description: What an awesome find, right in the heart of the tenderloin! While the area is gross, the food is worth coming for. Prices are awesome and portions are big. My friend and I had more than enough food just from splitting the Veggie combo. There are tons of vegan and vegetarian options too.
author: Eimanne Z.

description:
On a Sunday afternoon, I came here very hungry at a rather odd hour between lunch and dinner and ordered right away. Service was quick and friendly. My Vegetarian Combination came out in mere minutes. I stopped for a moment to take in the wonderful aromas and then proceeded to inhale the food so fast my stomach started to hurt a little.   

The combo came with Kik Alicha, Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen and sides of Azifa, buticha and salad. In particular, the Alicha Tikil Gomen (fresh cabbage, potatoes, and carrots cooked with onions, ginger, and tumeric) and Kik Alicha (chickpeas cooked with spicy tumeric, ginger, and garlic) stood out. I was mesmerized by the flavors.  
 
The Misir Wot (split lentil sauce made with berbere, onions, ginger, and garlic) was smoky and peppery. I don't think the combo I had came with Azifa (lentils sauteed with onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds, and lemon). The buticha (ground chickpeas, peppers, and onions) was delicious. Eating the collard greens (Gomen) made me feel extra healthy.  

I appreciated the hand wipe that was provided after the meal which seems to be customary at Ethiopian restaurants. And I love the Andes chocolates that came with the bill. Some of the customers were speaking to the staff in an Ethiopian language adding to the authenticity of this place. Don't let walking in the neighborhood deter you! It wasn't nearly so bad in broad daylight.
author: Lauren H.

description:
If you're craving Ethiopian food, Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen is an excellent choice.

FOOD:
+ Sambussa ($4.00): Stuffed with lentils or ground beef spiced with onions and peppers. We tried the lentil sambussas (aka. samosas), and they were delicious. 

+ Tibs: Choice of beef, chicken, or lamb sautéed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapeños, and berbere
+ Firfir: Choice of beef, lamb, or vegetarian. Small pieces of injera tossed in with the meat and Tadu's sauces

We ordered the tibs with beef and the firfir with lamb. If you've never had Ethiopian food before, you are in for a treat! There's a sink in the back where you can wash your hands, which you will want to do if you want to eat your food in a traditional Ethiopian way with your hands.

The tibs and firfir came served atop injera, a large piece of sourdough flatbread that is kind of spongy in consistency. The flavors of both were delicious. In addition to our two entrees, the injera was topped with a number of other smaller sides/dips/sauces. We were also given plenty of extra pieces of injera.

This is a pretty hefty meal, so be prepared to have leftovers! 

The ladies who work here are very sweet and helpful.

tl;dr: Yummy Ethiopian food with great service. Space is a little tight for seating, so don't go with a large group!
author: Lillian Z.

description:
Tadu is delicious! Good level of spice. 

The space is a bit small but I've never had to wait long at all for a table. Do wish it were possible to order a beer with dinner. For a sober supper, though, Tadu is a great option.

We especially loved the Vegetarian Melody-- mushroom and eggplant options are both great.
author: Anastasia Z.

description:
Tadu is a few blocks from our hotel and it was a good place for casual Ethiopian meals. I was looking forward to it especially, that I seldom get this type of cuisine that consists of vegetables and meats blended in special spices. 

When looking at their menu it took us awhile to figure out what's best. We had to ask if some of their items are portioned enough for three. Thankfully, their menu has a brief description for each item, which most we're not familiar with. But, in the end we left satisfied and what we ordered was mighty tasty. 

We went for the "Vegetarian Combination" ($11.95). Bedded on the bottom is the slightly spongey textured pancake, it tastes like sour bread. Then on the top is the split pea stew, spicy lentils, the tikil gomen its cabbage, potatoes, carrots and right down the middle of the plate is a salad. The vegetarian part alone may sound simple but, it was definitely full of flavor. 

I couldn't live without the meat so we added the "Chicken Tibs" ($9.95). We opted to have our chicken juicy and they didn't hold back on that, it was really tasty. You can see the tomatoes, and jalapeños within the sauces. Also, the spice level was medium and it does have a hint of pepper and lime taste. All I can say the tibs was stewed to perfection. 

Friendly service here, and I notice our server was one the cooks, nice multitasking from her. To dine inside it's a little tight in space when all tables are occupied, but hey  you can't complain about the cool mom and pop restaurant experience in downtown San Francisco. 

Located in the Tenderloin District, let Tadu spice up your lunch and dinner time.
author: Jon B.

description:
My first experience trying Ethiopian and man I'm kicking myself for waiting so darn long to try it especially when I was in Washington DC (where they have a large community and great restaurants). 

I had the kitfo regular . The meat was great as was the injera and the side sauce that they make.

The two women working were very sweet and you could tell they were familiar with people who were newbies to the cuisine.  

Great experience and yet another reason I like Yelp. 

The location is in the Tenderloin so the time you go here could be important to you (it doesn't bother me but I say this b/c I know it bothers/is important to note to some friends/colleagues who I've gone out to eat with).
author: Rod M.

description:
Well, let's start by saying that I know nothing about Ethiopian cuisine. I must admit that this was my first time trying it and, boy, I just realized all I've been missing.

Ordered the veggie combo, served with injera bread. Think a variety of spicy vegetable preparations, in different temperatures, some of them acidic and others not, with wild flavor combinations. Mesmerizing.

Minuscule dining room, like so many other places in SF. Attentive service. Colorful clientele.

And yeah, you get to eat with your hands!
author: Jaime L.

description: Awesome food. Friendly service. Great vegan options. The lentil Sambusas were excellent and the Veggie platter was a much more flavorful spread than what I get at home. So stoked to find this little gem.
author: Randy H.

description:
I really enjoyed the food at Tadu. Some coworkers and I shared a family-sized combo with an assortment of tibs and vegetables (misir, gomen, etc). There was plenty of injera and we ended up ordering another vegetable plate because everyone liked the greens and lentils so much. 

The place was slammed, with a line several parties deep out the door. The kitchen seemed to have a little trouble keeping up, but I feel like that's the right problem to have. All positives aside, the Tenderloin area is rough. We walked to Tadu from our hotel and in retrospect we should have taken an uber.
author: Gray S.

description:
I know everyone is saying it's authentic...but it didn't taste like Ethiopian. 

Yeah, I know it's Ethiopians (or Eritrean) and Mexicans? in the back cooking up a storm, but the food was like going to a Chinese Bamboo authentic restaurant with all Chinese staff and you find out that "real" mandarin food doesn't generally come from anything with Panda or Bamboo in the title. But instead they cooked for the popular masses...

That's how we felt at Tadu. High scores. Yay. But come to Los Angeles and go to Little Ethiopia and your taste buds will dance. You will will taste what you've been missing.
author: Mechell G.

description: Tiny delicious place close to UN Plaza. The injera is deliciously spongy and lightly sour. We had a salad of spicy tomatoes and torn injera on a bed of romaine, and a traditional collard green dish served with tiny spiced lentils, and other garnishes. Good strong Ethiopian coffee rounded out the meal. There are only 5 tables and the kitchen is fun to watch while you eat! Friendly speedy service made this a great choice before theater.
author: Laura A.

description: Delicious. I could swim in Berbere. Super authentic. The staff barely speaks English, but they get by with their charm. Injera was great. We had lamb ribs and Vegetarian combo. Literally finger licking goodness. Traditionally no utensils used. Eating with your hands could never be more enjoyable. Clean restaurant with good ambiance. At night there are a lot if homeless around, but they're harmless.
author: holly c.

description:
So glad to have stumbled upon this gem in the Tenderloin. 

Zero complaints here. The food was tasty, served quickly, and the owner is very approachable and friendly. Noticed quite a few locals getting takeout while we were eating here, and he knew them by name!
author: Sydney R.

description: As other's have mentioned, not the best neighborhood but you know once you're in you'll be treated to some great food. I'm a novice with Ethiopian so I asked the waitress for a recommendation and she led me to the vegetarian combo, with plenty of flavors on one plate. It's a good starter dish for someone new to the restaurant, but not all of the sides were good. This is a good place to try some new food in a casual environment.
author: Riley S.

description:
Good stuff!
 Extremely good vegan and vegetarian options and the servings are wonderful. The space is small and quaint but still cool enough for you to kick it and hang out if you please. 

The ladies of Tadu are just so sweet and so kind and are willing to make it just right for you. 
My husband and I love it and we're going back.
author: Milan F.

description: This restaurant was great! They had so many different vegetarian options and the food was very filling. They have many different combination options when ordering, so you can easily try many different foods in one plate. The restaurant was also very clean, and the staff was very kind and explained to us exactly what each food was. It's a self seating restaurant, so don't expect to go there with 15 people and have room for everyone to sit. Overall this place has great food, is vegetarian friendly, and great for small groups. I would definitely go again.
author: Meghna B.

description: Items missing from order, hair in food, grubhub support offered zero assistance. Shame because I love ethiopian food.
author: Randy B.

description:
Never have I ever ate Ethiopian food in bed... Until now! 

After a long week of work and travel, I was dead tired but it was Friday night and I was in San Francisco. Gotta live it up, right?! Well, on this particular night, "living it up" turned into ordering takeaway Ethiopian food with Yelp food delivery and cozying up in bed. Yes, I ate this messy, fragrant food in the comfort of my hotel room. Quite a different experience than I'm used to, but one for the books.

Now, don't think things didn't get a little crazy. Sure, I wasn't dancing at a club, but my heart rate was jumpin' as I briskly walked through the Tenderloin to find Tadu. I considered turning around and calling an Uber a couple minutes into my journey. Even in the daylight, I probably wouldn't walk through here again by myself. Even if it is 0.3 miles away.

My food was ready when I arrived. When it comes to Ethiopian food, the veggie options are usually my favorite so I ordered the vegetarian combination. I was also intrigued by their speciality, kifto, spicy raw beef. Yep, as if eating Ethiopian food in bed wasn't weird enough, I added raw beef to the mix. Living life on the edge, I tell ya. To cap it all off, I got a big bag of injera to sop it up. 

All in all, it was pretty darn good! I had never tried kifto before but am a fan of steak tartare which is somewhat similar. I could only have a couple of bites and there's no way I could ever finish a whole platter on my own because it's just too rich (and raw?). Loved the spice and overall flavor though. I basically ordered two entrees for myself and only finished about a third of the food before I was stuffed to the brim. It was all super hearty portions and a great price.

The restaurant itself is very small and casual. I would definitely venture here if I was craving Ethiopian (as I so often do). There's so much more I want to try!
author: Cassie P.

description:
This place was FLAVORFUL! Although walking to it from Union Square was a little sketch due to the homelessness, it was WELL WORTH THE VENTURE!

Highly recommended Ethiopian spot in San Fran!
author: Jessica D.

description:
Food was very good - I ordered the special kitfo, medium rare, which was served with some injera bread
Staff were extremely friendly
Will definitely come back, as I'd like to try the lamb tibs and the vegetarian combination next
author: Kevin P.

description:
Thank You Elias!

I've been living in DC (the largest Ethiopian Community outside of Ethiopia) for the past 17 years and had my more than fair share of my exposure of the Ethiopian Cuisine.
from the popular one like "Doro Wat" to the Raw Hanging Meat that the Ethiopians serves at their weddings "Kuert / Tere Sega" or "Milas Ena Senber" I know it all.
I had a very nice conversation with Elias the owner about some of the Restaurants and some of the unusual menus that the Ethiopian Restaurants serves in Washington DC / VA / MD area.
this place is good for those who are curious about Ethiopian Food and for the first timers.

try their "Kitfo" or "Special Kitfo" (since the owner is a Gurage Man) and the dish is originated from his tribe.

for real Afficionado, you don't get them in SF Bay Area.
you must come to Washington DC (U st) or VA (Skyline / George Mason Dr / Columbia Pike).
author: Rudy H.

description:
I decided to try Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen for dinner a couple of days ago as it had good ratings on Yelp. While going through its menu I was surprised that it did not have a meat combo (chicken, lamb and beef stew) that I generally get in any new Ethiopian restaurant that I try, as it gives you an opportunity to try different dishes from the restaurant in one go. I decided to get the Chicken Tibs ($9.95) which is chicken sauteed with Tadu's special sauces, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos and berbere using the on-line ordering app on Yelp.

A very painful part of this entire experience was reaching Tadu as it is in the heart of the hood (Tenderloin). While walking from FiDi you will cross a couple of homeless colonies spread out on the pavement and have to shoo off at-least a couple of determined panhandlers before you reach the restaurant. The good news is that my order was ready as soon as I reached and I was on my way back via a slightly longer route back that avoided the worst parts of the hood.

I got decent sized container having 3 sections, the largest one of which was filled with the Chicken Tibs, while the other two had some salad and green leafy vegetables. What I liked was they had not tossed the injera on top of the food making it soggy, something that other Ethiopian restaurants are notorious for, but instead had packaged it separately. Like most Ethiopian restaurants in NorCal the injera lacked the intense sour taste that is typical of injera from restaurants in SoCal. The chicken tibs were excellent. They were juicy and had a nice spicy kick. Even the green leafy vegetables were extremely good. Overall this turned out to be a very enjoyable meal. My only complaint was that this came with only one injera bread, which left me wanting a lot more.

Price wise this particular dish was pretty cheap for Ethiopian restaurant standards. Other items like the beef and lamb tibs were around the $15 mark. If you add another couple of bucks for the second injera you will end up close to the price point of other Ethiopian restaurants, so it's a little bit of smart price management here so as not to price them out of the hood. I'm confident that Tadu is one of the better Ethiopian restaurants that I've been to, even without having had a chance to sample a lot of their dishes at once. Well, it's all the more reason to come back and try them one at a time.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Really enjoyed this little hole in the wall. I've only had Ethiopian one other time and enjoyed it then too. I'm not a lamb fan but the lamb was exceptional.  Vegetarian platter was delicious. Hummus to die for. I'll never look at grocery hummus the same again. The beef sambusas were EVERYTHING! The only two things I wasn't a big fan of was the bread you use to eat the food. Too soon get and tangy. Personally I didn't need it bc the food was so good without it. And the flax smoothie drink. Otherwise fantastic!
author: Mimi M.

description: The location may throw you off, but the food and  customer service totally make up for it!! It was so good... loved the veggie plate and egg plant dish I got.
author: M W.

description: This place is so yummy!!!  Tibs is soooo good. The lady at the counter is really sweet and gave us different things to taste the last time we we're here. But top favorite Bay Area habesha place right now!
author: Mimi S.

description:
Such a hidden, hole in the wall...that every local person who loves ethiopian food knows about!  Haha.  I don't exactly know what authentic ethiopian food is but I eat it enough to know exactly what I like.  Tadu is up there with the best of them.  It's located right smack in the middle of the TL...the beautiful scent of urine just a few steps away.  Don't even think about that and just go in to experience some deliciousness.

Two must haves:  

Special kitfo - typically eaten rare but we went with medium rare.  This is Tadu's most beloved dish and what they're known for.  It's pretty much ground beef with jalapeños and seasoning.  Don't ask me what seasoning cause I have absolutely no idea!

Lamb tibs - Bomb.com...order it, don't look back, and just put it in your mouth.  Mmhmm...

Don't forget the injera.  If you need more, you can always ask but they give you plenty.  

The place is super small so you might have to wait for a table.  It appeared that most peeps ordered togo.  Super affordable prices.  Friendly peeps.
author: Jen W.

description:
My wife and I enjoyed a fantastic dinner with friends at Tadu! We started off with two orders of Sambussas, one veggie and one beef. Both options were delicious, and the slightly spicy dipping sauce was exquisite! 

For our main entree, we ordered two of the Vegan combos. It was a great call, as we were able to try a variety of all their different veggie meals. Our favorite of the bunch had to be  Misir Wot and Shiro Wot - both were to die for! For the nonvegans, we also ordered a plate of the medium rare  regular kitfo, which was equally amazing! 

Great service, friendly atmosphere, and we will definitely be coming back!
author: Omead A.

description:
Really nice service and people, I just wished that the food is good as well.

Tibs (1/5) really dry and tasted like it was reheated over and over again. The lamb and beef almost tasted identical, which is perplexing. forking through the tibs, you can tell that the meat wasn't carefully cut and prepared. There are lots of fatty tissue that isn't cleaned and separated. Giant sprigs of rosemary and halved (not seeded) jalapeño slap you in the face with their overpowering flavor (and I actually love rosemary and jalapeño). Were they in a big hurry? 

Vegetarian platter (4/5): solid Ethiopian dishes, nothing worth of mentioning.
author: Tata X.

description: I'm guessing I just don't like Ethiopian food.  The texture and taste of the bread was terrible and everything else was fine.
author: Shane S.

description:
This was my first time eating Ethiopian food. I loved it! The flavors were a little similar to Indian/Nepalese food but I overall loved the food.
I ordered the vegetarian option which was surprisingly very filling. 
The staff was very friendly. When I went there it was pretty empty, I think a lot of people don't know about this location since it's not in a prime location. 
I am not an expert on Ethiopian food but definitely loved my experience here.
author: Deki T.

description:
One of my favorite cuisines and best of all this is only a few blocks from our place. We've tried the tibs, the kitfo, the vegetarian combo, and the minchet abish wot. By far our favorites that we keep coming back for are the vegetarian combo and minchet abish wot. So. Freaking. Good.

Occasionally I'll go through Ethiopian food withdrawal and I'll need to binge-eat this stuff. Actually, who am I kidding? Every time I get food from here I binge eat. It's hard to know exactly when to stop, and when I've reached that stopping point I know it's already too late... injera (sourdough-like sponge bread) EXPANDS in your stomach! My favorite thing to do is to come here after a good long bike ride or exercise, to be famished, and then stuff myself to the brim with a deliciously savory and filling meal here. Always so satisfying. Once I came here two days in a row. Yeah, it's that good.

Sharing is probably one of my favorite aspects of Ethiopian food. Everyone becomes very intimate with each other as you share food using your hands from a shared plate. Of course, that's not required if eating with your hands sounds icky, but it's part of the interactive experience of the meal!

TIP: Seating is pretty tight here, so I'd say come with no more than a group of four!
author: Joanne Y.

description: A lot of Ethiopian places don't offer much for the individual order as they expect you to order as a family. This place allows you to do family style ordering which is traditional but they also have individual plates in case you don't want to share.
author: Zilla K.

description:
A gem in the Tenderloin; a few seats and a menu full of Ethiopian treats.  The vegetarian combination is very filling and reasonably priced.  I kinda of wish there was a meat combo, but instead all the carnivore options were just the meat with injera.  Guess I'll have to come back with a friend next time to justify getting the veggie combo *and* a separate meat dish.

Beef Sambusa: The sambusa itself was very similar to a deep fried empanada.  I suppose many cultures have the concept of wrapping ground meat in dough and then heating it in oil.  However, the red sauce on the side was amazing!  Had a little spicy kick, but not overwhelming.  Full of so much flavor that it really brought these sambusas to the next level. 

Vegetarian Combination: Loved the variety of 6 different items on one plate.  My favorite was probably the misir wot since I love me some berbere.  The kik alicha was pretty tasty too since chickpeas are a nice hearty pairing to the spongy injera bread.  The gomen was a little bland, but mixing those collard greens with any of the mushier items solved that issue.  The alicha tikil gomen seemed to have a better blend of spices adorning the veggies.  The small amounts of buticha and azifa were a bit intense by themselves, but enhanced the other items when a dab was added.
author: Adam B.

description:
Tadu is absolutely worth the trek to the Tenderloin. A and I came on a random Monday night when we were craving something different and we hadn't had Ethiopian food in a while. Let's just get this out of the way now: Tadu is in a particular sketchy part of the Tenderloin. I would not be happy had we needed to wait or if it was dark out. Tadu is pretty small (5ish tables) so I can imagine that on the weekend during peak hours, you would need to wait somewhere outside of the restaurant. There aren't a lot of bars or cafes to wait in the direct vicinity so you would need to walk a bit. Luckily, we got in right away and it was still daylight but I don't see myself coming during a period where I may need to wait.

Anyways, A beat me there by a few minutes so he had some time with the menu. Once I arrived, we ordered quickly and decided to split the Vegetarian Combo ($11.95) and Special Kifto ($14.50) which we had rare at the suggestion of the employee. We had our food relatively quickly and proceeded to dig in. Everything was served on a HUGE piece of Injera with a basket of more Injera on the side. The flavoring on each of the dishes was very good and I was happy that none of the Veggie dishes were bland as I have sometimes found in my limited experience with Ethiopian food. The Special Kifto was GREAT and definitely both of our favorites. The rare ground beef kind of scared me a bit but it was delicious. The spiciness was great. We devoured our meal and were pleasantly stuffed.

The prices were definitely fair for what we got. Next time, I also want to order the Sambussa appetizer which everyone around us ordered and we eyed with envy. I will say that the service was a bit odd. We couldn't figure out if we were supposed to refill our waters or if someone would come by and refill them. We never got any more water even though we asked. This happens so whatever but just an odd note.
author: Carrie W.

description: Food is amazing. Service is also very good. Kind people work here, and they want to make sure you are well taken care of and enjoy everything ordered. Highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Bekah B.

description: My first time ever eating Ethopian food. I went in to get some Injera and decided to order some Kitfo (think tartar to the 100th power). It came with Ayib (cheese) and Gomen (collards) and of course some Injera. I couldn't wait to get back to work, I had to try it in the car. OMG SOOOO GOOODDDDDD!!!!! I loved the sourness of the Injera. And you could tell it was a natural flavor and not some additive. So delicious. And the Kitfo was amazing. So smooth, tender, spicy, omg yum!!! I loved it. Absolutely loved it. I'm so happy I gave it a chance. I must go back and have other things. And the owner was an extremely nice man. I had a ton of Injera and he carried it to my car. Thankfully too. I couldn't get over how beautiful the Injera was. So gorgeous. Wonderful!!!!!
author: Yolanda A.

description:
Excellent and super affordable food. The vegetarian and the vegan options are clearly marked on the menu and they are plenty! 
It is a small place which makes it very cozy and you can see what's going on and by the kitchen as they cook and serve the dishes.
My friend and I had the vegetarian combination platter which is good for sharing between two people. 
The flax seed and honey drink (Telba?) is delicious.
A great find and the waitstaff is the sweetest. Recommended!
author: Nancy B.

description:
Mmmm! Hearty spicy Ethiopian made with love :) 
S
Light lunch turned into a feast. I only ordered 3 items for the two of us. 

Lamb tibs: spicy sautéed lamb and lamb ribs with bellpeppers onions and jalapeños that came with a lentil sauce, cabbage/ carrot turmeric sauce, of course about a pound of injera and this delightful herbed micro ricotta (ayub) and berbere 13.95$, 

veggie medley with bellpeppers, onions and mushrooms 9.95$ spicy and complemented the protein

ground beef sambussas 4$ for 3, similar to a wonton or jamaican meat patty with meat; with a side of delicious spicy sauce that had Turmeric and I think harissa. Definitely ordering again! 

Delish! 
We also had Ethiopian coffee which was extremely strong, like a slow drip black americano. Crack!

And the kelba, (cant wait to try at home to incorporate into smoothies) a rich yet refreshing slightly sweet blend of flaxseeds and honey.

Service was extremely friendly and warm and I believe the owner was our server. They know how to run a business. Bravo!
author: Megan K.

description: Ethiopian food is one of favorite foods. I came here with high expectation because of great the reviews from people. The food was not bad but we had it better at other Ethiopian restaurant in different cities. The lamb dish was a little dry as I remembered.
author: Choco W.

description:
Exploring the Tenderloin...post Color Purple at The Orpheum.  The spices wafting through the door convinced me and my son...we had picked a winner! 

We ordered Sambussa (deep-fried pastry stuffed with lentils) for our appetizer; Kitfo (ground beef sautéed with spices) and Gomen Besega (collard greens cooked with lamb). 

We ate family style and pinching our food with the Injera (bread similar to a crepe).  My only regret is that I didn't bring my other 2 sons so we could try more dishes.
author: Michelle P.

description:
Delicious Ethiopian food. They have tables, chairs, silverware (some Ethiopian places are a little too authentic and don't have those things).

The dishes I had were amazing:

gomen besega - collard greens with lamb.

lamb alicha banatu firfir - mild turmeric.
author: Bucky M.

description: The best Ethiopian I've had so far in SF. They actually have rare kitfo which is a little hard to find! Every part of the meal was delicious. Bonus points for being affordable and fast.
author: Mariko C.

description:
Delicious vegan, veggie and meat options. All in a welcoming family run spot. They're quick and so any wait is worth it. 

Great value for your money. Can't wait to go back.
author: Girl on the Bike s.

description:
I've only tried Ethiopian food a handful of times, but I've loved it every time and this place was not any different. 

The amount of seating here is quite minimal, so we were lucky to snag a table for 4. My girlfriend and I shared the vegetarian combo and beef tibs. I love when they serve the dish on top of a big piece of injera along with rolled up pieces of injera on the side. It's fun to eat the food with your hands and the veggies and meat were all very flavorful. 

It was such a pleasure to eat here and I'm sure i'll be back.
author: Edward W.

description: One of the best meals I've ever had! If you like Indian food you will love this place. We split the vegetarian combo with sambussa appetizer, it was the perfect amount of food for 2 people and really reasonably priced.
author: Kristin R.

description:
My all time favorite restaurant in San Francisco!

This is a cute little hole-in-the-wall kinda place with colorful Ethiopian vibes. This place is located in super shady Tenderloin area of SF. So, uber. Uber. UBER (or Lyft, whatever). Crew is just Wonderful and they invite us in with a Big smile that is sooo contagious. They are very attentive and agnostic to your needs.

Our favorite appetizer here is the Fitfit and close second is Beef sambussa. Fitfit has this surprising tanginess to it that just wakes up your taste buds preparing your tongue for the awesomeness that is yet to be served in the name of main course.

Our go-to main course is the Vegetarian combination and lamb tibs. Veg combo comes with lentils, wat, collard greens and cabbage served on a big-ass injera. And more rolled up slices of injera are served in a basket to keep you going. 3 different kinds of wats are served which have a lil kick to it. I can eat just the lentils with injera all day long. Also try their Ethiopian tea with honey. Perfect compliment to the flavor profile going on in your mouth.

The spicy hot powder that is served as a side IS. THE. BOMB. Just sprinkle a lil bit on your injera before diving into the dips and you can thank me later!

Fun fact: just gotta check mark on the receipt to tip, which makes tipping a no-brainer. Ain't that awesome? :D

My Ethiopian friend vouches for this place and so do I. Try it out. You wont regret it.
author: Sujeesha V.

description: Very Small place and not in the best neighborhood, but the food and service made up for it. Very friendly and quick service and the food was really good. I ate my favorite item, Shiro and savored it. Reminded me of all the Ethiopian food I ate in Kenya.
author: Sanath B.

description:
Most definitely one of my favorite Ethiopian restaurants!! My mom is quite a foodie, and didn't like Ethiopian food after I brought her to a different Ethiopian restaurant. I told her to give it one more shot& brought her here. this place totally changed her opinion on Ethiopian food!! We've been here 2 times in the last week 

Usually order the veggie combo.. nice to get a little bit of everything. 4 different Ethiopian dishes & served w salad and injera (pancake like bread). I don't know why but my mom loves how this place slice the injera into smaller pieces (most Ethiopian places I've been to serve the injera in giant pancake shape)

some Ethiopian places don't seem to have the best service.... (not sure why)... but this place was very friendly. the lady that cooks& takes orders is very nice& welcoming 

will definitely be back!
author: Lauren E.

description:
I doubt you can't go wrong with anything in the menu. We had the Gomem Besega and the Mysir Wot and both were delicious, with the Mysir being hot & spicy. The Gomem Besega was mildy hot and I personally don't prefer hot food, but this was just about perfect for me. 

The portions are generous, so actually servings can be shared. We shared coffee and it was rich, thick and bold, heaven! Service is friendly and definitively looking forward to going back and try something different.
author: Lorely G.

description:
Ethiopian is incredibly vegan friendly and you can't get much better Ethiopian in the city than Tadu (for an upscale experience, check out Radio Africa Kitchen). All their veggie dishes are pretty much vegan so for those who sometimes second guess like me, this is a vegan SAFE place! And if in doubt, ask the incredibly friendly wait staff who are patient with first timers and veterans alike. I highly recommend the veggie combo which comes with:

- Gomen: collard greens
- Alicha tikil gomen: cabbage, potatoes, carrots
- Misir wot: split lentil (my favorite!)
- Kik alicha (chickpea)
- And sides azifa: lentils (ridiculously good), buticha: ground chickpeas, and salad
- With a basket of injera

This is a small place (4-5 tables) usually full of other Ethiopians, so come early to beat the rush.
author: Jay C.

description:
Last weekend we were in SF, and I had to get my Ethiopian fix. As we did not want to go to the East Bay and were staying Downtown, I decided to try out Tadu. As others have noted, it is located in the heart of the Tenderloin which is not for the faint of heart. But then we folks who love unusual cuisines don't get freaked out by bunches of homeless, some of whom you have to step over.

The food was good. The kitfo was prepared raw as we had ordered it. They even brought us some mitmita. We also had chicken tibs and the veggie combo. As is not too uncommon, the meats were spicy while the veggies were more on the bland side, including the misir wat. Unfortunately, there is neither wine nor beer available, so we had to do with water. Overall, if in the area, this place is a great option.
author: Nobbi L.

description: Amazing food. The woman who owns it is so sweet. She helped us figure out what to eat. It was quiet. Loved it.
author: Jen H.

description: Came in around 3 pm on a Saturday. I ordered the chicken ribs and the dish was delicious!!! They were serving slow but the food quality was good. Big portion too. Barely finished it.
author: Mandy Z.

description:
Excellent food and service. Simple and casual. They have good gluten-free vegan options. Take your time and enjoy it. 

Neighborhood can be rough but it's worth it. Metered street parking is around $2.50/hour.
author: Jazmin H.

description: I love this place.  I order the veggie sampler once a week with extra injar for me and my boyfriend. The food is cooked with love and care. Prices are reasonable.  Portions are generous. Eating with your hands is also just fun.  I prefer take out and have never had a problem with my order.
author: Shirley V.

description:
We went to Tadu for dinner after watching sunset from battery spencer park. We found valet parking in a nearby garage for about 15 bucks. Street parking is available too but it's a bit challenging to find a spot. Also the neighborhood looks a little unsafe. 

Tadu is a small place and there's around 6-8 tables. We were lucky to find a spot as soon as we walked in. It's a little cramped in there but the we really enjoyed the food. We got 2 veggie combos and two sides of chicken tibs and one side of miser wot. We also tried the Ethiopian coffee and it was so good! The staff were really nice. We had a very satisfying meal.
author: Arthita G.

description:
Tadu is great if you know what to order and what condiments to request. I really hope this location stays around for a while because they're so damn unique.  I'm also appreciative of restaurants who state which items are vegetarian & vegan right on the menu. The knowledgable staff here help further fine tune what you might order if you are the enlightened type who trys to avoid consuming animal products. 

They are awarded stars here as such: 

1. Ambiance: It's comfortable and they there's wonderful Ethiopian decorations
2. Food: the stews are all very flavorful. Their spicy hot powder, available by request, is just what you'd need to bring the heat up a notch
3. Tadu is Vegetarian & Vegan friendly. They know their ingredients so they can advise which dishes will suit those with self imposed dietary restrictions. 

I couldn't give Tadu five stars because, for me, the fifth is reserved for restaurants who offer vegan proteins (e.g. TVP, Gardein, Beyond Meat etc.). However, had 'Yelp!' offered reviewers a choice of several celestial bodies, I would have awarded Tadu four stars and one crab nebula! 

WHAT TO ORDER?: Get the vegetable medley  (with eggplant  or mushroom)  and Vegetarian combo‼. The injera bread is made with teff & millet (i think) so that's always cruelty free.

Maybe this is too much to ask but I think the problem with all Ethiopian restaurants is that they have yet to offer vegan mock meat proteins. Vegans are a loyal subset of the Ethiopian restaurants. Given the smaller selection of choices we have for restaurants they can expect a higher return visit rate from the vegetarian community. I wish they could work in bulk vegan food items as outlined in guide for restaurants who want to offer such things such as this one below: http://www.mercyforanimals.org/VRGFRNational.pdf
author: Athonia C.

description: Absolutely thrilled to find this spot so close to work.  Took my mom and fiance for lunch. Had a wonderful meal and the staff is lovely
author: Mimi M.

description: I have been here a few more times since the first review and I love this place even more now. Very tasty food served with a great smile. Had to update review to 5 stars.
author: Balu V.

description: Veggie combination plate is heaven on earth. Best Ethiopian in San Francisco, hands down.
author: Hawley S.

description:
Had the chicken tibs and they were delicious! They don't sell beer but you're allowed to bring in beer from the outside (liquor store on Jones st) 
Friendly staff.
author: Joe R.

description: The owner is so nice. Cute place. Great veggie sampler and kifko. Have tried a lot of Ethiopian food in the city and this is one of the best! Go get your Ethiopian fix!
author: karen l.

description:
I've had this spot bookmarked for the longest time since I love Ethiopian food -- glad I finally had a chance to try it!

Nice small family run restaurant with impeccable service. They checked on us multiple times to see how the food was & if we needed anything. Like all the Ethiopian restaurants I've been to (& it's honestly quite a few!), there's a sink outside the restroom since it's customary to eat with your hands. Look mom, no utensils! 

We started off with the Beef Sambussa appetizer which was perfectly crispy & very flavorful -- a must order! If you're not quite sure what to order, the veggie combo platter is a good place to start & to that depending on how hungry you are, you can add some protein dishes. For two people, a Veggie Combo Platter plus Lamb Tibs was more than enough. In fact we were stuffed silly but a good kind of full since the food was so delicious! The veggie platter came with yellow & red lentils as well as collard greens. My favorites were the lamb tibs & yellow lentils. I love the experience of eating Ethiopian food because it's very colorful & the spongy injera is the perfect way to scoop up bite sizes of deliciousness. They must've recognized my friend who is a regular since they gave us complimentary dessert.

Perfect for smaller parties. It's a small spot so if you come with a party larger than 4 you might have some difficulty finding a large enough table. They deliver via Eat24. 

Tadu, thanks for the wonderful food & great service. Looking forward to the next visit!
author: Ruby C.

description:
I am reminded to write this review because I overheard a man talking about Tadu on the train. Being from Ethiopia, he raved about how good the food is here.

Tadu is a small hole-in-the-wall restaurant in the TL. There's a few tables, so it's not good to come here with large groups. Though if you do, the staff will make it work by piecing together tables. You may have to wait a bit. There are 2 staffers who work very hard.

I don't eat Ethiopian food enough to know whas da bomb, yet I really like what I tried. The veggie combo, meats, etc. were delicious. The staff were generous in giving more injera bread. And we got free baklava pieces for dessert. I'd come back!
author: Joanna L.

description:
This place has deliciously authentic food, serves it in large & affordable portions, and tops it off with excellent service. I was recently in Addis Ababa and would say that the food here is comparable if not better than one of the best restaurants there.

They have a great selection on their menu - you can pick between a variety of vegetable and meat dish options. Best of all, they have a rare, beef tartare-like dish that I haven't been able to find anywhere in SF. The food is incredibly authentic (though based of my n=1 Ethiopian food impression), hearty, and comes with unlimited injera. The portions are also huge, the prices are extremely affordable ($15 for the large beef tartare-like dish). You will leave happy and stuffed. 

The staff are also incredibly nice and friendly. The service is great and they were open to providing recommendations and educating you on the dishes.

The only con here is that the space is small and the location is a bit dodgy. It can be hard getting a seat, but they do offer excellent and fast (10 min wait) takeout options!
author: Amy G.

description:
Excellent food and service! We had a great experience at Tadu from the moment we walked in. The space is small but we got a table for two immediately at 8:15 on a Saturday night. We ordered the beef sambussa, veggie combo and lamb tibs. Sambussa were flavorful and perfectly crisp. They also came with a really good dipping sauce (next time I'll ask them to keep that at the table for the meal--it's a great condiment).

Veggie combo and lamb were perfect. I liked the lentil wat and cabbage/potato the best. We weren't crazy about the salad in the middle. The lamb tibs were cooked perfectly! The njera here is really light:airy and not too sour. It was the perfect accompaniment!

For about $40 including tip, this is now one of our favorite places in the nabe.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
This is one of the best Ethiopian restaurants in the middle of the city. I don't even think this location is on yelp. I don't know the process but the owners need to update the location. We randomly stumbled upon this place with a colleague and decided to give it a try. While it lacks the Ethiopian culture, the food is amazing, large portion and is prepared pretty fast. The bread comes straight from Ethiopia, you should try it, it's pretty awesome. We had an opportunity to talk to the owner "Elias" I think that's his name but I am not sure on why the restaurant name is Tadu. We have him the compliment and feedback and he told us about the idea behind it. He explained how he wanted to serve as many lunches as possible around the area without being labeled as a fast food restaurant. I liked the unique idea and reason behind it, my other feedback is the size of the sambusa, it's amazing but small. You get 4 per order and we each had 2 but were craving for more. I wanted to go back today but my schedule didn't work out, I highly recommend this place.

This particular location is on 1120-30 4th street, you can see the address on the flyer.
author: Daniel K.

description:
I am absolutely excited to have found this place! The food is authentic with the usual traditional dishes, but they've also made some modern variations which I must come back to try.

The place itself is a small restaurant with an intimate setting of a family-run business. The staff are quick, friendly, and welcoming.

We got the vegetable combination plate, lentil sambussa, and chicken tibs and they were all superb. The chicken tibs was definitely a favorite of ours!
author: Jacqui C.

description:
Love this little hole in the wall with super authentic Ethiopian food. My Ethiopian friend highly recommended this place. Also another added benefit: no corkage for wine served! We got the veggie platter and the lamb tibs. Super delicious. Love the Ethiopian bread that's soaked with the lamb sauce. Get the moderate spice to have a bit kick in the food. 

Service is great. Fantastic for a laid back night and we will be back!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Tadu, a simple enough counter with no booze, offers above average Ethiopian food with fresh injera, spicy enough food and well prepared wots and tibs dishes. Service is friendly and efficient. I have had better but this place isn't bad.
author: Eli L.

description:
The injera is second to none in this place! If you're a little adventurous be sure to grab the raw beef dish! And follow it down with the flax seed drink. I go here regularly ever since I moved to SF. 

I would suggest going to he Tenderloin branch over the SOMA location... the ambiance just seems more authentic there! :)
author: Nabil R.

description:
Was here for dinner last night, after getting to see Hamilton (bragbragbrag). First off, yes, the reviews mentioning the unsavoriness of the neighborhood have a bit of a point. I really thought they were exaggerating - it's SF, not Compton, right? - but yeah... it's only 4 blocks from Orpheum Theater, but during that 4 block walk, my wife was catcalled by two different homeless people. 

Worth it, though - we have had a lot of Ethiopian food, in a lot of cities, and this is up there. It's not at all fancy, but the food is excellent. We tried: the lamb tibs (great quality lamb, though I did feel it was a little too salty), the michet abish wot (I hadn't had that *specific* wot before, so I can't compare it exactly, but it was one of the best ground beef-based Ethiopian dishes I've had, plus I'm always happier when Ethiopian dishes come with ayib, which, theirs was some of the best in that respect too), and the veggie combo, which was also great. 3 dishes for 4 people pretty much filled us up (though my mom doesn't eat that much, or we probably would've wanted one more). 

I want to specifically call out their injera, which I think was the tastiest, most flavorful injera I'd ever had (maybe whatever's in the SF water that makes their sourdough so good?) I also want to call out how fast we got our food after we ordered - normally I expect Ethiopian restaurants to run a bit slowly, but we got our food in like a few minutes, despite how fresh it clearly was. We also asked what "telba" was (I haven't seen that before), and were given free samples of it (which was good, as it was totally not what I was expecting, and I would not have enjoyed it - tasty enough, but way too thick to be particularly refreshing), and when my wife ordered a baklava for dessert, instead they gave us one for free. My mom also said the coffee was excellent (I'm not remotely an expert on coffee, so I can't corroborate, but she is, so I trust her.) 

Highly recommended. Though yeah, don't come here with a group larger than 4 (even that was a little bit of a stretch), and maybe don't walk here by yourself after dark.
author: Adam F.

description: I've been to a few different Ethiopian restaurants but this is the best by far!!!!! The spices are on point and they have more selection for us non meat eaters! I definitely will be back
author: Yusmine B.

description: Went here for an early dinner on a Saturday prior to watching a movie. We figured this would be a perfect place as one of our group is a Vegetarian. We ordered the Lentil Sambussa, Vegetarian Combination (includes Kik Alicha Wot, Misir Wot, Gomen, Alicha Tikil Gomen, Azifa, Buticha, and Salad), and Chicken Tibs. This was plenty of food for 4 people when eaten with the Injera. My favorite was a combination of the Kik Alicha Wot, Alicha Tikil Gomen, and Chicken Tibs. SO much flavor between the tang of the injera, spice of the vegetables, and the meatiness of the chicken made for the most amazing bite. Please note, this restaurant is very small, so not good for groups, but would deffinitely be good for takeout.
author: Crystal S.

description:
This is a nice little oasis in the tenderloin. I started with the excellent Ethiopian coffee, to which I added ridiculously heavy-seeming cream. We had the vegetarian combo platter and the chicken tibs, which we asked to be brought out together on a big plate with injera underneath & a bountiful basket of rolled injera alongside. There was *so* much food and I thought it was pretty delicious & made for wonderful leftovers.

The biggest difference I found between Tadu & other Ethiopian/Eritrean food I've had is that it tasted a bit "fresher" and less slow-cooked/stewed. I'm not sure if this was a time issue or a stylistic one. Honestly I prefer the long-cooked method where the flavors meld together more and everything softens up, but this was good too. I found it especially noticeable in the gomen (greens) and kik alicha. Also, our alicha tikil gomen ended up being almost entirely cabbage.
author: Lisa K.

description:
A nice place in a shady neighborhood

We had the Ground beef sambussa appetizer which was our favorite and we ended up getting a second order because we liked it so much 

We had the tartare like ground beef and the veggie combo plate with endless amounts of the injera bread. We had to take leftovers home!
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I got spit on my a homeless guy (yep, that's the Tenderloin in SF for you) in order to get to this place and try it, on a whim after watching an episode of Diners, Drive Ins, and Dives in which Guy For was eating some tasty looking Ethiopian cuisine. The few staff here are very friendly. It's a very cozy and homey feeling spot.

Let me tell you, it was worth it.
I got the Vegetarian Combo plate so basically, I got to try half the vegetarian options on the menu.

The Misir Wot was so flavorful and had a great texture.

I thoroughly enjoyed my first experience with injera, as well. The strange but inviting texture and slight sourness added to the entire culinary experience. 

The Alicha Tikil was piping hot! I kind of almost burned my mouth on it in my sheer excitement to try everything on the plate. Very tasty with the carrots though. Mmm..

And I love chickpeas. So the Alicha Wot was probably my favorite thing on the plate. Well..It all was very good so I can't play favorites.

Definitely a must try if you can make it through the TL. (Civic Center Bart station is closest, I made the mistake of getting off at Powell) 

Bring friends! And bring your appetite.
author: Angela S.

description:
The best part about this place is the woman who is cooking. She is so nice and you can tell she puts a lot of love into the food. Wonderful on a cold night when you need something to warm you up. I had the vegetarian sampler, and it was very good with some spicy dishes and lots of good flavor. I loved that they brought a whole basket of injera to eat with your meal. Portion sizes are generous. This isn't someplace I could go every night, but I could see craving it once it a while. This would be a fun place with kids because you eat the food with your hands; I thought that part was fun, too!

I visited here on a Monday night at about 7:30 and had to wait for about 20 minutes. I'm not sure if that is normal, but I would go earlier next time so I didn't have to wait.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Best Ethiopian food i've had, and I have had a lot (admittedly in the US, not the source). The flavors are intense and amazingly different from one of those little piles on the injera to the next. I highly recommend the Vegetarian Combo (on the specials menu) and Lamb or another Tibs. This will serve 3 and probably 4 people.

Lamb was ridiculously good, grilled and then mixed with a flavorful sauce of onions and tomatoes and a bit of heat. Even a couple of little bones to suck on. I looked up the dishes on the veggie combo and most are variations of lentils and chickpeas, yet each tasted completely unique.

I have been trying to make injera and had a conversation with the cook about how they make theirs which is excellent. It's mostly teff but does have some wheat flour. There is an imported, gluten-free pure teff injera available but the house made is better and also cheaper. Get that unless you are gluten intolerant.

Tiny place, zero atmosphere unless you count the friendly people and the homemade drawings on the walls. But who cares... you are here for the food and it is great.
author: Otis M.

description: Excellent food and service. Location sucks in the TL. Homeless, drug use out in street but well worth the walk! Great service
author: Briana M.

description: My 21 year old daughter took us to this place after raving about the food.   The  people with me were all 40+ and never had Ethiopian food so to say it's an acquired taste was an understatement.  Not a knock on the establishment (the waiter, and staff were nice and the food was affordable priced) but the older crew I was with wasn't feeling it.
author: Randall S.

description: THE best restaurant in San Francisco! My husband and I absolutely loved this place: 5/5 for the service, atmosphere, food, and overall experience. This was our first time eating Ethiopian food and now we're hooked! We forgot our credit card too, and the boss kindly held it for us until we returned. If only we lived closer...if we're in the area again we will definitely be back! Thank you for the lovliest dinner! :)
author: Elise Y.

description: My first time having Tadu. A bit on the spicy side for my taste pallet BUT flavorful and satisfying nonetheless. I would recommend! I had the veggie combo with injera plus sambussa with lentils.
author: Danielle H.

description:
We ordered the special kitfo with the vegetarian combo. Girl friend doesn't like raw meat so we ordered the kitfo well done. Loved that it was still juicy. 

When we asked for the bill we got a complimentary baklava. Which was unexpected and delicious. 

Best Ethiopian food we have ever had. We will definitely be back.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Fantastic family run Ethiopian food. I've been here every month with my boyfriend for two years and can't stop. Sometime twice a month if we're feeling it. Been to several other places in sf and the east bay and nothing compares. The folks here are endearing and so friendly. Super fast in food prep. I always bring new folks here, because it's the best food in my opinion around. Heart, soul, culture, spice and love. The lamb tibs are to die for and so is the special kitfo--rare of course! Any-who, I've had everything on the menu and you truly cannot go wrong. The vegetarian options are sooo good, you don't even realize you're missing out on eating meat. What better way to support locality, diversity, culture and FOOD in sf. Be ready to eat with your hands!

Hands down to these guys. Small kitchen and staff, but fantastic service and food. Never longer than 30mins.
author: Angela N.

description:
This was our first encounter with Ethiopian cuisine and this place brings in amazing dishes which we felt in love with. 

Food:
We ordered vegetarian combo which included Alicha Tikil (potato, cabbage and carrots cooked with ginger, onions and turmeric), Misir Wot (red sipcy lentil), Gomen (collard greens) and Kik Alicha (spiced chickpeas). All this came with Injera which is East African sourdough risen flatbread. We loved almost everything. The vegetarian combo was brilliant in taste - each and every item. Injera was a bit more sour - a little less would have been better. 
Inspired by the food, we also ordered Ethiopian coffee and spicy tea. However, perhaps, that's where went overboard with experimenting and failed big time. I won't recommend the beverages but the food is amazing

Ambiance:
It's a small place, just enough to sit may be 10-12 people. Perhaps good for takeaways. Quite congested, so may be not good for large groups. However, you get to see the food made since the kitchen is right in front. Interiors are decorated with couple of pictures on African theme. 

Service: 
It was quite good and quite fast. Not sure why the owner doesn't smile (may be an off day for him when we went). 

Overall, it's a nice place. Definitely visit, in case you haven't tried Ethiopian cuisine
author: Jay M.

description:
That's the third Ethiopian restaurant I've been to in SF, and by far the best one! Prices are reasonable, perfect amount of food (we had a bit leftovers). We ordered the Veggies Combo and the Lamb Tibs - which is SUPER spicy, but tasty. The neighborhood is a bit dirty since it's downtown SF, but thumbs up to the restaurant. It's pretty small, but the staff makes up for it. Baklava for dessert also really tasty!
They do deliveries
author: Bruna D.

description: My cousin and I came here when we decided to broaden our palettes. And let me tell you it was so worth it! The food is packed with flavor and so nicely seasoned. We had a platter with chicken and beef and it tasted so good. Also the servers were really nice and gave us so much of that Ethiopian bread with the holes. Definitely worth it!!
author: Jenny B.

description: This is my favorite Ethiopian place! Glad to hear they finally opened up another location close to AT&T Park! Everything is delicious. I recommend the lamb dish if you're into that.
author: Theresa N.

description:
The next time someone comes to visit San Francisco and asks me where to eat, this will be at the top of my list of recommendations!! I have not had Ethiopian food in years, and Tadu reminded me of everything I was missing out on. The food here is incredible, and I'm starting to crave the Lamb Tibs and House Salad as I'm sitting here and writing this review. 

I came here at around 6:30 PM on a Friday evening. That or earlier is probably the best time to show up, because there are only a handful number of tables in this restaurant, and by the time I left with my friends, there were tons of people waiting outside. On that note, come with 2 to 4 people per table. This is not designed for large groups.

The Lamb Tibs were incredible. Very fresh, flavorful, and filling. I especially loved the house salad. It sounds simple, but the dressing is so so addicting. Personally I could not finish this plate alone, but then again I have a tiny appetite. I'll be back very soon and very often!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I went with two girl friends to Tadu last night and was extremely pleased. I walked over to Tadu from Union Square and didn't feel the most comfortable walking alone through the Tenderloin, so just take note of this if you decide to come by foot in the evening. 

It's a small place but was well-packed when we arrived. I asked for a table for three, and the girl working there quickly ran to the back to grab two chairs to join a table with a single chair. We started off with lentil sambussas (samosas), which came out super hot and fresh with BOMB spicy sauce! 

My friends are both Vegetarian, so we ordered the Vegetarian Combination (lentils, cabbage, collard greens) with Shiro Wot (ground chickpeas that had a consistency of a thick, refried bean paste) to share. Injera came separately in a basket. The flavors were fantastic, and it was definitely a good idea to split it between the 3 of us! We especially enjoyed the Shiro Wot and lentils. After we finished the huge platter, the girl brought us a small plate of baklava that was "on the house", which was such a pleasant surprise. 

The man running the show was super nice and definitely gave Tadu a warm, home-y vibe. Friendly service, great bang for your buck--I'll be back.
author: Christine T.

description:
This is unexpected find! 
It looks inconspicuous from the outside, just like any regular mom and pop place. There are some small tables cramped together on the inside for intimacy among the guests.
But boy, don't let it fool you! Who cares about the look when they got the bomb food?

One portion of beef berbere banatu was enough for two of us. (we even struggled to finish it!)
It's a hearty tender chunks of beef mixed with pieces of Injera. The spice! I don't know what's the exact combination of the spice is, but the flavor! Spicy, right amount of salt, a bit sourness and delicious aroma. And how fun it is to eat with your hand as you scoop the meat with the injera?
And that vegetable side dishes they got? I want a tub of it.
What a bang for the bucks. It seems like it's family run too which really gives it a homey vibe. (Support more family owned venue!) 
This shall be my go to for Ethiopian fare.
author: Jenny T.

description:
My first time trying Ethiopian food and Tadu did not disappoint! I ordered beef sambussa for an appetizer and the vegetable combo with lamb tibs for my entree, which could have served 2-3 people. Wish I could have brought my leftovers back home with me but unfortunately I had to head straight to the airport afterwards for a flight. The beef sambussa came with a spicy sauce and was piping hot and delicious. It was a bit on the greasy side, but extremely yummy. The vegetable combo and lamb tibs was presented on an unfurled piece of injera, which is a spongey sort of flatbread. The first thing I thought of when I looked at it was my slight case of "trypophobia" (don't look it up on Google if you're uncomfortable with images of clustered, small holes)...but the subtle taste and texture was amazing. There was also a side of extra rolled up injera for you to eat the wat (Ethiopian stew that has a similar consistency to hummus). I personally LOVED the types of wat I got - they were so flavorful and some of them definitely had a kick to them.  The lamb tibs were also quite yummy and I loved the smokiness to them. 

Ambience-wise, the place is quite colorful and cute. It's very small and probably only seats less than 20 people. The food comes out very quickly. One slight detraction to the restaurant is its location in Tenderloin, a neighborhood that slightly gives me the heebie-jeebies as a young woman by myself. As I did not feel comfortable walking in the area, I simply Ubered to and from the restaurant - no big deal. The food definitely makes this place worth it! And the service was awesome. Check it out!
author: Katherine Z.

description:
This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and fortunately it was very good.  If not, I would have been turned off to Ethiopian cuisine.  The restaurant was a bit in the shady area of San Francisco but well worth the trip. It was dotted with more of the homeless and indignant rather than gangs so I didn't feel unsafe when I went in the late afternoon daylight hours.

For the restaurant itself; small cafe style with about 6 small tables.  Clean, well kept, homey, and comfortable, nothing fancy.  It looked like about 60% of the business was take out.  Since this was my first experience with Ethiopian food, I didn't have a basis to compare the food with but I can tell you everything was fresh, flavorful, excellently prepared and unexpectedly well presented for a small cafe restaurant in the Tenderloin district. I would describe the food as tasty comfort food that you could easily develop a craving for.  Portions didn't look much when I first got it, me being a "healthy" eater but it was more than enough to fill me up.  I think the Injera bread has a lot to do with it.

A family run business and I really appreciate the friendly, caring atmosphere where customers are made to feel as a guest in their "home", a lost art with most business nowadays. 

My wife and I had the Sambussa.. Tasty with a mild spicy sauce on the side. Nicely packed, so you actually can taste the stuffing. Lamb Tibs.  Grilled tidbits with onions and spices.  This was really good having a nice seared flavor.   Vegetarian combination.  Great way to try all the different Ethiopian prepared veggies.  Each has it unique flavor, some mild, while others are a bit more spicy.  I like the spicy Misir Wot the best.  I had a small cup of Ethiopian coffee which the owner gave me for free to try We also got a complementary Baklava and Spiced tea (they forgot to give us our Spice tea during our order) (a typical example of how customers are treated as a valued and appreciated "guest").  Boy the Baklava was good too, being not overly sweet having a flaky pastry.

All and all, excellent experience and tasty food at a reasonable price.  I have now developed a comfort food craving for Ethiopian cuisine and for this establishment.  Thank you Tadu!!!
author: Edwin L.

description: Best Ethiopian food I've had in SF! Tadu has an extensive array of vegetarian options and the injara was delicious. We will be back!
author: Hannah S.

description: Delicious first experience. The vegetarian combo was excellent and flavors were great. The walk up the restaurant is a little rough the service was sweet and the food delicious
author: Joshua D.

description: Food was great. The lady working the front made me feel uninvited, But I often get that vibe from the younger women workers in Ethiopian spots. Food was a bit greasier than normal also, but I let it sit in fridge over night and it stayed liquid which tells me it's ok for my body even with so much. Besides that the food was very good and high quality. I was feeling pretty slow and heavy all week, and like always some good quality ethi food had me feeling all better in the morning. Felt light and nimble again. 4.5/5 stars if workers are nicer and food is slightly less greasy.
author: Darrion H.

description:
My second time trying Ethiopian food and it did not disappoint! I like this place more than Enssaro, where I first tried Ethiopian food in Oakland. 

This place is pretty small only 5-6 tables but it's very neat and has modern decor. It's also family ran :) a little boy served us our water. 

I really like the injera here because it wasn't too sour. We order the vegetable combo with lamb tibs and it was sooo good and flavorful! 
Warning: the lamb tib is pretty spicy!! 

I remember really liking the potatoes and the fresh greens in the veggie combo, which went perfectly well with the spicy lamb tibs. The veggie combo + lamb tib was A LOT of food for two people and I think the portion could've fed 3-4 people. However, my bf and I didn't know how to order smaller portions. 

I was a little iffy using my hands to eat but they're super cleaver for having a sink outside of the bathroom. 

All in all, this place is a must try!
author: Leilani Y.

description: Not bad but chickpeas are over purified and have way too much garlic, not made fresh (just scooped out of hot pot), no gluten free injera, and lack of Ethiopian setting.   If you are from SF and have never had Ethiopian sure you will think it's fine.  If you lived in DC for over a decade and took your wife on your first date for Ethiopian good you will be let down big time.  Much prefer places in the tenderloin.  Also $18 for a veggie lunch dish was WAY over priced.  Maybe it should be two stars but the lady was nice.  Note they did NOT have gluten fee options when I was there.
author: Matt H.

description:
Food was very tasty especially the lamb. The mushroom was a hit as well. The beef was a little tough but the veggie combo was a good experience to try the different variety lentil and other veggies

Interesting location in the heart of the tenderloin. A few coworkers and I came from fidi for Ethiopian food and will come back
author: Allen G.

description:
I love Ethopian food and have been looking for a go-to spot for quite some time. Tadu is the perfect casual gem in the TL.

I was pretty surprised how small this place is - probably 10-12 tables total. Feels very casual, almost like a cafe! Don't come here for a fancy date - come here for simply good Ethiopian food, in a home-y/casual, no-frills environment.

They have a pretty straightforward menu, lots of people end up sharing the Vegetarian Combo ($13) and a meat dish ($13-16). I dined here solo and ended up going with the Vegetarian combo - everything tasted fresh and piping hot. The portions are generous and made easy to share with their Injera.

The ladies in the back are continuously churning food so seems like it's constantly made fresh!
author: Veronica S.

description: Very flavorful, made fresh . Chicken ribs and every single veggie dish is excellent . Best Ethiopian I had in sf
author: Sandhya K.

description:
Five stars for the authentic eating experience, service, and amazing food. I ordered the chicken tibs and my friend had the veggie plate and it was served together on the same giant plate. I also got the ground beef sambussas.  The sambussas were fried perfectly with a sweet dipping sauce. The chicken had so much flavor from the spices, peppers and onions. 

Tadu is deep into the tenderloin. My friend and I had to dodge piles of poo and she gagged the entire way from the urine soaked sidewalk. It was worth the trip, though!
author: Lisa X.

description: I was there with my friend. We ordered tgis enormous plate for two :). Very nice place.
author: Akash S.

description:
Great place with nice spicy firfir. The seating is very limited so you will probably be a little uncomfortable. But that describes SF in general nothing against the place.

Just go!
author: the u.

description: First time trying Ethiopian food and it was very very good. The employees were friendly. The prices were reasonable and I had a great meal. I recommend coming here for Ethiopian food.
author: Joseph M.
