description: I've been a lover of Ethiopian food for some time & i gotta say this place is pretty delicious. This placed turned my extremely picky Jamaican boyfriend into a lover as well. Every time we're in San Fran he wants to come back for more. Even the presentation on your plate is beautiful! The injera = delicious, veggie combo = delicious , kitfo =delicious... I posted a picture a while back of the kitchen staff and although they are not Ethiopian they definitely know how to cook the food! Tadu I'll be back soon for some of your delicious food.
author: Brittany N.

description:
TL;DR:

Quite decent in the realm of Ethiopian, though I'm puzzled by their lack of a proper Wot offerings.

THE DEETS:

***VEGETARIAN COMBINATION - Kik Alicha (chickpea), Misir Wot (split lentil), Gomen (collard greens), & Alicha Tikil Gomen (cabbage, potato, & carrot) with sides of Azifa (chilled dish of lentils & mustard seeds), Buticha (chilled chickpea spread), and salad

Pretty solid, no standouts but no complaints. In contrast with competitors in the area, they also add little side dishes that seem to be mixed with dairy (I believe the Azifa & Buticha) that I swear don't taste like lentils or chickpea--difficult to pinpoint what else is in there. Unexpected but interesting.

***REGULAR KITFO - Lean ground beef sauteed with special spices and homemade butter. Served with a side of Ayib (cheese). Spicy & Hot. (served rare of course)

Nice & buttery, I approve. I like a little moo with my beef (raw or rare). They seem to serve as tiny bits rather than actual ground beef, which is an interesting & unexpected approach. 

***LAMB TIBS - Lamb sauteed with Tadu's special spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapenos, and berbere.

I've never really cared for tibs, which are kinda okay but just not as creamy, tender, or flavorful as wot. But they don't have any wot offerings, which is disappointing. 

***FIRFIR - LAMB ALICHA BANATU - Small pieces of injera tossed in Tadu's sauces of mild tumeric with lamb. Mild.

Quite nice. This dish highlights why Ethiopian leftovers are always better the second day--the injera gets soft, mushy, and even a bit more fermented, which sounds like it would be gross, but during this process everything becomes super-infused with flavor.
author: Elliott D.

description:
Very very delicious. I went with three friends for my birthday and we had the Sambussa (which unfortunately were still frozen inside), the Vegetarian Combination, a lamb dish and spicy tea. Amazing food and very affordable. My belly was very happy!

The only drawback was that my friend, when paying, didn't receive his card back. Understandable, as it was a crowded day. He realized it once we'd left the restaurant, and noted that when he went back to receive it, the staff did not apologize for the inconvenience it caused him. 

I agree with other reviewers that the service can be odd (we asked other diners who had ordered if we could have their menu after waiting for a bit and not receiving on) and that the neighborhood isn't the best. Despite these small things, I definitely plan to go back.
author: Astrohfiziks A.

description: I was impressed by this spot!  Wasn't expecting too much waking up to Tadu,  but like they say "it's not about what's on the outside but what's on inside"!  This is as authentic as it gets.  The meat was well seasoned with different herbs and spices and the collard greens....let me say could  give my moms  greens a run for the money (but that's moms so she would wins by default). Swing by.....you won't be disappointed.
author: Eddie B.

description: The flaxseed and honey beverage, telba, was wonderful.  My veggie combination was more of a mixed bag.  The flavors were excellent for the misir and shiro wot's, but a bit flat for the alicha gomen.  Didn't bother me, but the Tenderloin district has a large homeless population in the vicinity of the restaurant.
author: Sean K.

description: They kindly served us even though it was passed their closing time. This was my first Ethiopian experience...it was good but I was missing meat. That was my fault though bc I shared with my vegan friend (bad idea)! Otherwise, the food was good and flavorful. The bread wasn't too sour (I've heard it could be really sour), and I enjoyed it with all the toppings. Reminded me a lot of dosas (an Indian dish) which I am familiar with and know I enjoy sometimes!
author: Sandi S.

description: Delicious food, excellent value, good service. After a day in Sonoma we found this place on yelp and decided to stop by. Though we arrived just a few minutes before closing, the staff was still very accommodating and welcomed us. We ordered the veggie platter with the special kitfo (lamb). The food was delicious. The injera was very fresh and had a great texture (could realty taste the sourdough)! Only thing missing would be an alcohol menu :) delicious and very filling! Worth the trek to the tenderloin.
author: Yin H.

description: Excellent food at an affordable price. Fast, attentive staff. I'm so glad we found this place and can't wait to go back!
author: Julia C.

description:
Running out of lunch options at work, I turned to Yelp who had a philosophical question for me. Would I be willing to make my way through the jungle (The Tenderloin) to seek out treasure beyond my wildest dreams? I'm happy to report, this Safari was an adventure well worth the journey past the mumbling crackheads offering oratorial rewards in exchange for their next hit, feces of the dog and human kind littered throughout like pancakes at an IHOP buffet, and just the wretched smell of ..well you get the point.

The place is tiny. We had a group of 5 and it was a little tight sitting at one table but we made due. The menu is simple enough - there's lunch specials and there's the group share-family style entrees, which is what we did. We decided to do the vegetarian sampler which come in big dollops of various veggies - creamed chickpeas, some collard greens, lentils, etc. and we paired the veggie sampler with an order each of the chicken, lamb, and beef tibs - basically cubes of meat simmered in the house sauce. All of this is served on Injera - a bread that looks like a pancake but it's greyish-purpleish and it was explained to me that it was made out of grain that has been imported from the homeland. There's a sour taste to it and I know it sounds weird but it goes very well with the food.

You eat with your hands by scooping up food with Injera (there's also extra Injera served besides the one used as the "plate") or if you are weak, they can give you a spoon and fork. But that defeats the whole purpose of trying this type of food - it just does not taste the same unless you eat it how it's meant to be eaten. Food was delicious and service was great. I liked everything we had.

The only qualm I have was that I felt as if the portions were a bit small. For the price we paid, I expected a little more. We were 5 hungry, growing boys, and we all felt a little hungry after we devoured our meal. 

All in all, a great experience and will definitely come back!

PS - don't try to correct me in my reference to the bread. It's Injera. To call it "Injera Bread" would be like calling lumpia "Lumpia roll" or Chai "Chai Tea". Like Madam Miriam Defensor would say - it's a redundancy, student!
author: Ray R.

description:
Ethiopian food isn't my normal go-to joint, but I'm fortunate to have some adventurous friends. My buddy suggested we meet there for a long, overdue hangout.

We shared the beef tips and vegetarian platter. While it doesn't look like much, the injira bread does an amazing job of filling you up. I really enjoyed all of the spicy (in a fragrant way) flavors and the beef was cooked to perfection. We even got a free slice of baklava for dessert!

I can't say enough good things about Tadu. It was delicious, service was fantastic, and I loved every bite. It might be in a rougher part of town, but it's worth the day trek for some amazing Ethiopian grub. Stop on by and give it a try!

Food: 10/10

Service: 9/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
I am a meat lover but this place converted me to a vegetarian for a brief 1-hour period!

I went with a couple of friends. I ordered Beef Tibs and my friends ordered Misir Wot and Mushroom veggie. The Tibs was what you would expect in any good Ethiopian place. But their vegetarian dishes were so yummy with their soft injeras!! The Misir Wot was spicy, tangy, flavorful, awesome, tasty, lovely, gorgeous... :D 

Portion sizes are large so please go with friends. They'll love it!
author: Ram R.

description: Nice small restaurant. I went with three other people and we got a veggie platter with cube steak and chicken. The steak wasn't the greatest but we all enjoyed the chicken.
author: Madisyn A.

description: This is one of my favorite Ethiopian restaurants.  It's very small however the service and food is right on spot.  The owner is very friendly and came out to chat with me.  I asked about the spices and he even gave me some samples.  It's been a year since I've been back and really need to return.
author: Kenji M.

description:
The combination of trying to find a restaurant in walking distance that was open midday on a Sunday and having not had Ethiopian food for ages led me to Tadu. As it's located in the Tenderloin, we walked past the numerous homeless people that are unfortunately so common there. 

After perusing the menu, the three of us decided to share the Vegetarian Combo, which includes the Kik Alicha (chickpeas), Misir Wot (spicy lentils), Gomen (collard greens), Alicha Tikil Gomen (carrots/potatoes/cabbage), Azifa (lentils), and salad. The star of the combo was the Misir Wot, which had great flavor and a little bit of a kick to it. The other items were pretty typical and not especially interesting (have yet to have them anywhere where I thought they were great).

In addition to the vegetables, we had the lamb tibs and beef tibs. The lamb had a nice, strong lamb flavor to it. To our dismay, the beef tibs were tasteless. In addition, the two dishes are prepared in exactly the same way, so the contrast in flavors (or lack thereof) was especially noticeable.

Plenty of injera for our meal (they asked if we wanted more, but we were already full). We certainly overordered as we had leftovers.

Overall, this is somewhere between 3 and 4 stars. I've decided on the lower rating due to proximity to the homeless--if you are walking around with a child, you feel a bit unsafe. I will say that when we were inside the restaurant, we had no concerns about safety.
author: Terence T.

description: Very small place with limited seating. The food was pretty delicious. And the service was super friendly and attentive.
author: Hanna D.

description:
Priced lower by $2-$3 than most Ethiopian joints, this tiny shop is great for very casual dining.

The veggie combo is a must. There were two dishes in it that I'd never had before, both of the ones that come on the salad, which you can see in several of the pictures from others. They're interesting and good, though not my faves. The cabbage and two lentil dishes are awesome. So good and spiced just right.

We also got the Fitfit appetizer (interesting but so so) and the Shiso. The Shiso is basically seems like Ethiopian hummus, and it's so good. Incredibly smooth and velvety.

We only got the veggie dishes this time because those are always good at any Ethiopian place, whereas meat dishes are more often miss than hit (they tend to be dry or chewy, despite the large amount of oil surrounding them), but we'll give one a shot next time.

Also, their receipts are kind of genius. Why isn't check box tipping more common!?
author: Andrew R.

description:
TLDR: flavorful Ethiopian food, large portions, very reasonable prices; definitely recommend for a different dining experience

I've seen Tadu listed as one of the "Best of Yelp" Restaurants for many weeks now (maybe since its opening?). I've yet to see a place maintain a 5-star rating for so long and with 100+ reviews, so of course it made my bookmarks list. Honestly, if fellow Yelper Ben K. hadn't suggested it for dinner, I don't know if I would've ever made it here since I don't like to frequent the TL.

The restaurant is a small hole-in-the wall with maybe 5-6 tables and probably has the capacity for only 15ish people. In contrast to the surrounding TL, the inside is pretty nice and clean. The place wasn't busy yet at around 6pm on a Friday, but it filled up pretty easily and there were people waiting by the time we left.

Anyone unfamiliar with Ethiopian food (like me) might be a little lost with the menu, not because there are too many options, but because everything sounds more or less the same. The menu has a few appetizers and several veggie and meat entrees, which all come with injera, a spongy sourdough crepe. I'd recommend the SAMBUSSAS as a starter and LAMB TIBS as an entree. And you can't go wrong with the VEGETARIAN COMBO, which will give you sampling of almost all the veggie entrees. The food overall was pretty tasty and I really enjoyed anything cooked with berbere (some sort of chili/spice).

For anyone who hasn't had Ethiopian food, there are no utensils (unless asked for). You basically break off pieces of injera and use it to pick up the meat/veggies or dip it in the more hummus-like veggie dishes.

Entrees range from $10-15 and portion sizes are big and filling, especially with the unlimited injera. One entree can easily feed you for 2 meals, so it's definitely worth the price. Being the fatass that I am sometimes though, I ended up eating much more than I should have..

Service is pretty good here. Our server (who I think may have been the owner) checked in on us a few times to ask how the food was and to see if we needed more injera or water.

===========

SAMBUSSA ($4) - 5/5
Comes with 3. Kind of like samosas, but the dough is thinner, airier, flakier and crispier, and the inside is filled with ground beef or lentils. We got the ground beef, which was amazing! A little bit of spice and so much flavor

LAMB TIBS ($14) - 4/5
[sautéed in spices, onions, tomatoes, jalapeños, berbere]
Juicy and delicious! The jalapeños and berbere give it a good kick, but more heat would've been even better. The dish was on the greasy side for me but tasted so good that the greasiness couldn't stop me from eating more of it

VEGETARIAN COMBINATION ($12) - 4/5
We ordered the vegetarian banatu/firfir, but I'm pretty sure they gave us the veggie combo now that I'm looking back at my picture. The vegetarian firfir is supposed to be vegetables and pieces of injera in berbere but we definitely did not get that on our plate. The veggie combo didn't disappoint though and was a really good sampler of many of their veggie entrees

     -MISIR WOT - 4.5/5
     [split lentil sauce made w/ berbere, onions, ginger, garlic]
     Orange/red and similar in texture to a thick tomato sauce. A little bit spicy from the berbere, which I loved. Definitely one of my favorite veggie options
     
     -ALICHA TIKIL GOMEN - 4.5/5
     [cabbage, potatoes & carrots]
     Another favorite from the combo. Not as flavorful as the misir wot but I like that it actually has veggies in it

     -GOMEN - 3.5/5
     [collard greens]
     A little bitter but still pretty good

     -KIK ALICHA WOT - 3/5
     [chickpea cooked w/ spicy tumeric, ginger & garlic]
     Yellow and a little thicker than hummus in texture. Not bad but didn't impress me

     -BUTICHA - 3/5
     [ground chickpeas, peppers & onions]
     Reminded me of a potato salad in taste and mashed potatoes in texture. I actually liked the flavor but it felt pretty rich and heavy so I could only eat a few bites

     -AZIFA - 3/5
     [lentils sauteed w/ onions, jalapeno, ground mustard seeds & lemon]
     Served cold. Also kind of rich/heavy

VEGGIE MEDLEY ($10) - 4/5
[mushrooms stir fried w/ peppers, jalapeno & berbere]
Solid. Not super special and pretty greasy, but very flavorful

KITFO ($13.50) - 3.5/5
Flavorful lean ground beef, cooked to a nice medium rare. I liked it a lot at first but wasn't really a fan of the half raw ground texture after a bit

INJERA (complimentary)
The entrees are served on a giant piece of injera. I've only had Ethiopian once before and didn't like the injera much because of the acidity, but was pleased with the injera here. Theirs was soft, spongy and tasted like sourdough without being too acidic. I don't really like sourdough in general so I wouldn't eat the injera on its own, but it works well with the entrees and soaks up the juices of the lamb very well
author: Jessie L.

description:
Tadu freaking ROCKS!

Was really craving Ethiopian food and after not finding anything comparable to Seattle, I decided I didn't care and wanted to try this place (the five stars lured me in).

The first time we came here, it was an hour before closing to find that there were no seats and it was SUPER packed. There's only five tables, so plan accordingly. We waited and waited, and thankfully right before they closed they kindly seated us.

We started off with the vegetarian sambusas (ask for the hot sauce, it spicy and delish). The edges were perfectly crispy, we practically inhaled them.

Next up, the vegetarian combo, beef berebere banatu, firfir, lamb tibs, and shiro wot (so I know this is a lot of food, but leftovers are the best, so whatever).

Bf ate the ENTIRE veg combo by himself. Not only is it super flavorful, it's massive (one of those can't stop eating, it's so delicious), and you get enough injera to swaddle a newborn baby elephant in. 

They even brought us a bite each of baklava since we waited outside for an hour for a table. So nice (and so yum).

I absolutely love the beef berebere banatu, and shiro wot. We never come here and not order both of those. 

Also, they have gluten free injera (FROM Ethiopia!!), like no joke. Order this (+$3) and you'll leave without feeling fat, no matter how much you dig in. It's a bit more tart than the regular injera, but so so delicious, absolutely fluffy, and perfectly moist. I never skip it. I gladly take the the left overs home and make my own berebere firfirX (lentils, chicken, etc.) to enjoy for another day. 

The staff is always so helpful, very kind, and remembers you. 

Seriously addicted to this place.
author: Shereen A.

description: I'm a fan! Get the lamb tibs...ok yes Ethiopian food is always full of flavors, but this spot really makes it apparent. I literally closed my eyes with every bite. They give you great portions and its literally cooked fresh a few feet away from where you're dining. I mean come on, what else do you want? The kitfo was great too..I should've order rare and not medium but still delicious! The injera was a plenty and delicious as well. The prices are good especially for being in San Francisco and you get more than enough food. I wish they had some honey wine, but that's ok it's hardly a complaint, merely a wish. We will definitely be back.
author: Guisela L.

description: Came here earlier in the year with a friend of mine that put me on to this amazing little spot! Highly recommended to check this place out! Kitfo was supreme
author: Mario S.

description:
I love Ethiopian food but a good place is hard to find. My friend and I were seriously craving some the other afternoon, but the one in the Mission doesn't open until dinnertime. So we found Tadu in the TL, which has 5 stars. And it really lived up to its rating! There are only a few tables inside so when its busy, I can see why there would be a wait. There aren't that many items on the menu, but everything on it is delicious.

I highly recommend the lamb tibs. It's made fresh to order and is absolutely delicious. The onions are perfectly caramelized and the seasoning of spices and salt is perfect. So yummy!

We ordered the full size of the Alicha but they accidentally gave us the veggie combo, which is fine. The veggie combo was great. We loved the cabbage, lentils, and chickpeas. I also liked the salad a lot too. The collard greens were good too.

We also ordered the Beef Sambussa as an appetizer. There were only 3 but the filling was spicy and yummy.

Next time, I really want to try the eggplant (which they didn't have a half size of) and some of the other meat dishes. The pictures look awesome!
author: Sherry L.

description:
I tried out Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen one day for lunch.  It's a tiny hole-in-the wall in the Tenderloin, Ellis St & Leavensworth St.

I got the Vegetarian Combo $11.95. You gotta eat with your hands eating Ethiopian food - Right hand!  You can wash your hands in the sink area in the back. 4 different veggie dishes on top of injera, a small salad with 2 dips on the top.  More injera given in a small basket.

I liked my dish.  Would like to try some meat dishes next time.

I paid Cash, not sure if they take credit cards.
author: Ann L.

description:
We took my in laws and my kiddos who are first times at Ethiopian. Amazingly - the kids ate it without too much drama and the ILs also really enjoyed it. The injera was yum and we all
Liked the yellow lentils. Place was a bit small and would love to see them expand and have the traditional tables to eat on. Great overall experience - staff was super nice too!
author: Jeeta G.

description: I am glad I tried it and actually liked it good service as well
author: Antonia G.

description: Great fast-food Ethiopian restaurant. Loved the veggie combo and would come back. Parking was limited, as it's first-come street parking. I also missed the "Ethiopian restaurant" feel - it's very tiny, and there are no Ethiopians tables. Deducted one star for atmosphere. Otherwise, great food, especially on the go.
author: Erica S.

description:
I've only had Ethiopian in San Jose (Zeni), and Tadu wasn't quite at that level, but it still hit the spot. Bonus points for curing a terrible case of post crappy $40 hotel breakfast buffet hangry-ness.

We got the Sambussa starter which came with three pieces of fried flakey dough stuffed with ground beef and onions. Tadu's version is extra crispy, the filling is seasoned well, and the tomato dipping sauce was fantastic.

At the recommendation of our server, we chose the Lamb Tibs in addition to the Vegetarian Combo. The Lambs Tibs were juicy, but could have used some more seasoning. In the veg combo, I enjoyed the Misir Wot (red lentils with Berbere spice) the most. I also liked the buticha, which the server compared to hummus. It was made from chickpeas but much thicker than hummus, and reminded me of potato salad.

The Injera bread was not as sour or fluffy as I prefer, but that didn't stop me from eating an entire basket anyway. Injera is my weakness. There's something about the act of scooping up food with bread that I absolutely enjoy. Service was attentive and kind as well. Tadu is worth braving the sketch area for!
author: Adrienne H.

description: This was by far the best Ethiopian food I have had! I came here for lunch and ordered the Vegetarian Vegan Combination plate and was greatly impressed by the huge portion! Everything was absolutely delicious as well as the Telba I ordered. The 2 women working were so nice and I even had a complimentary Baklava. Amazing food and amazing service. I am definitely coming back soon! Thank you so much!
author: Kavi S.

description:
Great food, great service!
We came in here on a week night. Since my wife is a vegetarian, she ordered Misir Wot. I ordered chicken tibs. The entrees come with unlimited injera bread and a cabbage side. 
The food was really amazing for both of us and we sure shall be here again. Keep it going guys!
author: Neil S.

description: Unfortunately, my palate didn't find the food to be delicious.  I'm a vegetarian and I need food to taste great without meat. I think the food needed to be spicy. The cook and cashier were very friendly.
author: Genevieve C.

description: The delivery was fantastic very fast super friendly....food not so much. I eat Ethiopian on a regular but the beef tibs was not flavored the way I'm use to for sure. The Alicha was very greasy, and the salad with yogurt eek...what happened to oil and vinegar. I guess they do it different in San Fran then back home. Oh well $40 down the drain even my spiced tea wasn't right.  Oh well to each their own.
author: M M.

description: I can't say enough great things about Tadu.  Even if you're new to Ethiopian cuisine, you're sure to find something that can please your palate.  Highly recommend!
author: Elizabeth J.

description: Its such a tiny place that it is easy to miss while driving by. What it lacks in space, it makes up for in taste. Their service was great too. We requested for gluten free injera and they obliged. Then i said only one of us needed gluten free so we got both types. I especially loved the grilled peppers and mushroom dish called Veggie medley. However, I knocked a star off because of the small portions. We ordered the Veggie combination which i was to share with my partner but it was too little for the both of us and the collard greens and cabbage and lentil dishes lacked the flavor or punch of the mushroom dish.
author: Madhuri G.

description:
**HANDS DOWN TO THE BEST 5 STAR ETHIOPIAN FOOD JOINT IN THE SAN FRANCISCO (TENDERLOIN AREA)**

Count me in, where do I sign up? I had no idea this place existed until a friend of mine and I decided to try some Ethiopian food. He chose the place and I have to say for my first time I sure wasn't disappointed!

I arrived around 7pm and decided to take transportation since the area is not the BEST area in San Francisco. This location is not far from the Civic Center Bart Station.

When we entered the place was packed house. Please note: This restaurant is VERY small.

We were able to get a seat in the back. The owners were very nice making sure we felt comfortable. After we let him know that it was out first time coming to the location he gave us a couple mines to decide on the menu.

After looking at the yummy pictures on Yelp we decided on:

APPETIZER:
-Beef Sambusa- VERY GOOD!! 5/5 (tasty sauce to go with it)

~INJERA:
Your meal is not complete without Injera! The spongy, unleavened bread, which acts as a plate beneath a quintet of stews and we used it to transport the delicious food to our mouths. RATED:5/5

MAIN MEAL:
~Lamb Tibs- sautéed lamb leg with deeply caramelized onions and rosemary. RATED: 5/5 Comes with a little spicy taste, but nothing you can't handle.

~Beef Tibs- Very flavorful and good! RATED:5/5

DRINKS:
~Telba Drink- ground flax seeds in water and sweetened with honey. The taste is not for everyone but I enjoyed it. It tastes like a healthy morning drink but I have to admit that the taste is refreshing and good for you!

Everything was really good and tasty. The owner was able to spend time in teaching us a little history about the drink Telba and states that depending on how Ethiopians were raised the drink can be given on special occasions but some athletic people drink it as well since its good for your digestive system. The drink was given as a sample to use before we actually bought it. 

After being stuffed from the huge meal that was just presented to us, I had the nerve to ask for something sweet (like the food wasn't enough)

The owner came out with a plate of Baklava which was the topping to the night! Baklava is a rich, sweet pastry made of layers of filo filled with chopped nuts and sweetened and held together with syrup or honey. Let me just admit that it's SO good and a must try! What made it more special was that the owner said it was on the house! HOW NICE! Complimentary dessert!

As you can see, this place is GREAT and the food is something that you just have to taste and experience. 

I was so full and happy leaving that I couldn't help but plan my next meal to order when I come back!

My first time trying Ethiopian food was the BEST experience I could ask for!
author: Porsche C.

description: I came here to introduce Ethiopian food to my roommate and it is by far one of the best Ethiopian places in the Bay area. We ordered the veggie combo with lamb tibs. The gomen was a little bit too salty, but the lentils and cabbage were delicious. This meal was of great value, especially in SF. I would definitely recommend this place if you are in Tenderloin. It is little seating so probably not a good place for parties of 4 or more.
author: Shu T.

description: Hole-in-the-wall (but clean), great service (we came on a Friday night at 6pm, and it started filling up as we were finishing our meal, so come early!), tasty Ethiopian food, and best of all - really cheap! 4 of us shared 2 veggie combos and an appetizer, and it was the perfect amount. The waitress didn't try to upsell us or anything! What a delicious dinner. The neighborhood is a bit sketchy, but that's to be expected.
author: Jan Z.

description:
I'll keep it short. Food and service both top notch. Place is clean. Simply amazing. Ask them to make it spicy if you can handle it. 

We had the special (raw, not rare) beef kifto, lamb ribs the veggie combo and injera washed down with the flaxseed drink. Too much food for 2 people but we almost finished all of it.
author: Rori G.

description:
Have been here many times for lunch with colleagues. Food is really good, tasty and with several options. Rare beef and lamb are very good, as well as all the vegetarian options I tried so far.
The prices are very reasonable and the service is extraordinarily friendly.
I personally like this place better than "Cafe Ethiopia" on Valencia Street.
author: Xavier R.

description: Great food and attentive service. The space is tight. There are few meat dishes on the menu, but they are succulent. The injera is nice and sour.
author: Therese M.

description: Great tasting food. Small place and not great ambience but the food makes up for it. Good service. The flax seed telba drink was good. Gluten free injira was good.
author: Meg S.

description:
My husband and I love Ethiopian food, so we were very excited to learn about Tadu. We came relatively early on a Saturday evening and there was a pretty long line already. We were hoping that the line would move quickly, but given how small their space is, it took longer than the time quoted. Normally I wouldn't mind but the restaurant is in a BAD area; during our wait we saw a drug deal occur two doors down, and we were constantly yelled at or solicited by passerbys. When we finally sat down, I realized how small their actual kitchen was and worried that we might be waiting quite some time for our food. Thankfully orders were placed quickly and food came out relatively regularly and quickly. 

We ordered the sambussas (both veggie and beef), which were very good, along with the vegetarian combination plate and the chicken tibs. I liked that everything was presented on a large injera, so that all of the juices could soak in. The food was very tasty, although not noteworthy. The ambiance (or lack thereof) of the space made it less of an enjoyable experience.  Plus, given the small space and lack of music, you could overhear all of the conversations around us. I'm sure they are running a clean kitchen but the space just felt tired and a bit rundown; I think it really needs a complete interior renovation. I think if we eat here again, it will be take out rather than sit down.
author: Regina L.

description:
Yabetta caaall Tadoooooooonnne!
Butya can't use myy phoooooone!

Bc too busy photogging my food.
(^_^) Beef Tibs #spicaaymissyelliott
(^_^) Lamb Tibs #datcartilagedoe
(?_?) Rib Tibs (they were out!)
(^_^) Hot Sauce #dontwearasweater
(^_^) Telba #cracklinoatbran
(-_^) Spice Powder #alsonosweater
(-_^) Baklava #sweetsweetback

Terykah Tadu is a refreshing gem in a literally stizzank area. #donttripyouknowaintnothintender You can bet I #whitneyhoustonxkevincostner bodyguarded frendo afterward ALL the way from the restooooo to the ride! to the ride!
author: Dan B.

description:
Small, Authentic place in the heart of city. We ordered takeout and when I mentioned it was for a birthday party, the owner gave some baklava on the house. He even offered to walk everything over since I couldn't find parking. 

The food was great. Injeera was fresh.
author: Pallav S.

description: Don't let the outside fool you, the food is delicious , the lady cooking is beyond sweet and hospitable , and you can tell she puts love in the food she makes . Highly recommend  this place,  amazing food, great price, only 5-6 tables but worth the trek into the TL.
author: Chef B.

description: I enjoyed my time at Tadu. The food was good, customer service was spot on, but what prevents me from giving it a full five star review is the fact that I was expecting a bit more flavor and spiciness. Otherwise this was, for lack of a better term, perfect.
author: Melissa B.

description:
So I probably should have read the review a little closer when I went here - I was definitely under the impression that it was a sit-down, full on restaurant. It's more like a fast casual model with amazing food. Something I'd never experience with Ethiopian before - I usually prepare my self for a 2+ hour experience when doing Ethiopian. 

Small tables, limited menu, no booze (pretty sure). But super friendly people that were more than happy to provide some recommendations for us. 

We ordered the lamb and chicken tibs and the veggie sampler. All of it was amazing. It had been forever since I had had Ethiopian, but this was definitely some of the better dishes I've had. The lamb and chicken was super tender and simmered in some amazing sauces - deep and rich with spices on the lamb. My favorite veggie were the collard greens, they were tangy and delish, and not overcooked and wimpy like greens can tend to get.
author: Rory J.

description:
Another treasure hunt led me to this compact Ethiopian spot deep in the 'Loin. Again a waft of positive Yelp reviews gave me the courage to gird my loins after dark and find my way to Ellis between Leavenworth and Jones where this cafe resides. Even though it was just past 8PM by the time I arrived, it was nearly full up with diners who didn't look like they were going anywhere soon. Luckily by the time I ordered at the counter, the front table opened up. I asked the woman at the register what she recommended since I was unfamiliar with everything on the menu except kitfo and injera (photo: http://bit.ly/1Dt2tGn). Kitfo is a bit like Hamburger Helper, Ethiopian style, which is not a bad thing but probably more meat-heavy than I had in mind for an entree.

In the meantime, who wouldn't want to start with an Ethiopian empanada called Sambussa, where you get three large, deep-fried turnover-like creations filled with lentil beans, onions and peppers? A trio for $4 struck me as a good deal, and it was, especially with a huge ramekin of a light marinara-like tomato sauce for dipping (photo: http://bit.ly/1EST1vN). For my entree, I decided on the $12.50 Gomen Besega, a house specialty that takes a huge round of injera, the spongy native bread of Ethiopia, and then covers it with cooked collard greens mixed with bits of minced lamb, garlic and onion. There was a thicker version of the tomato sauce on the side, which I think mixed in mashed lentil beans, as well as a fresh salad (photo: http://bit.ly/1ESSTfG).

On top of this generous portion came a basket of rolled injera which they served like bottomless mimosas (photo: http://bit.ly/1FwgaE4). By the time I depleted half of it, more injera came out as if it somehow multiplied in the kitchen. No matter since I happen to be a fan, and this one had a less vinegary taste than I've had at other Ethiopian spots. I was full by the time I was halfway through my entree, so I asked for a box which they happily provided. The owner came by to see if I enjoyed the food, and he shared with me his story about being a cabbie who dreamed of opening a place where he could serve his grandmother's recipes. Mission accomplished as the food has a very home-style flavor to it that tempers the exotic aspects of the cuisine. I plan to come back in the daytime when I can more freely walk there.

FOOD - 4 stars...home-style Ethiopian with the most flavorful injera in town (sorry Moya!)
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a bit tight in space but the interior is brightly lit and clean
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...quite friendly and accommodating
TOTAL - 4 stars...if you're in the mood for Ethiopian, this is no Tenderloin trap
author: Ed U.

description:
Very friendly people, and amazing food!
It was my first time trying Ethiopian food, and absolutely a fan now!
Food tastes fresh and homemade style. 
Their lamb tibs and veggie combo were to die for. 
I will DEFINITELY recommend *****
author: Sara S.

description: We got here before the Sunday dinner crowd. We received great and friendly service and attention. Being our first time here, we went with the Vegetarian Combo and added the Lamb Tibs for us carnivores. While waiting for the entrees, our server presented us with Sambusso, "on the House"!  That was unexpected and greatly appreciated. The injera was fresh and all the flavors were wonderful.
author: Jim M.

description: This place was great! It was my first Ethiopian food experience and I am hooked! I've been dreaming about the wholewheat sourdough flatbread ever since, mmmm so fluffy. We went for the share patter vegetable combination plus the beef tibs, and this was plenty for two hungry diners. No boring flavours here, each dish was delicious. A great place to head with a vegetarian friend. The interior is clean and the service is friendly. I'd be here all the time if I lived in SF.
author: Laura D.

description:
Embarrassing admission time. I really, really love kitfo. I might love it as much as I love my SO. I've ordered kitfo in like five different countries because, for whatever reason, I just start craving it after a couple days (the best we had in Europe was in London, the worst in Paris -- go figure). I can't really speak to the authenticity of Tadu because I've never stepped foot in Ethiopia or in an Ethiopian home, but this is still by far my favorite place in the Bay Area for kitfo. Get it raw, sprinkle on some extra mitmita if you want even more of a kick, and enjoy. I promise that you won't regret it (unless you order something like three kitfos on top of a tibs and veggie dish for four people -- even I will admit that we went a little overboard). 

For two people, we usually order a kitfo and a veggie combo and it's the perfect amount of food. The lamb tibs are also fantastic if you insist on getting something cooked. The restaurant is fairly small, so expect a wait if you're heading over during peak dinner hours and a bit of a struggle if you're trying to seat a party of 8 or more people.
author: Elaine L.

description: Loved this place! Literally a hole in the wall! To tell the truth, I was definitely skeptical about getting good Ethiopian food without everyone in the kitchen being Ethiopian but I was definitely proved wrong. Everything was delicious and spicy like the way I wanted. They have some different options like Ethiopian sandwiches and stuff but I am not sure about that yet. Loved all the traditional combo options.
author: O K.

description:
Tadu's foods were so nice! Also nice people!! I went here with 3 of my friends around 7pm. There were one space for 4 people and others were for 2 people. I recommend to go here not with big group however if you are less than 4, here is nice to eat! I ordered Vegi Combination and my friends ordered something with lamb meat. 
All of them were so nice we really enjoyed a lot!
author: Kim Y.

description: Small hole in the wall Ethiopian place with great food! I'm vegetarian and there are lots of veggie options which I loved. I got the vegetarian combo so I could try all the veggie dishes and my friend got the kitfo. Both of us were very happy with the meal and the prices were very reasonable. Service was great too since there werent too many people there but the only downside is that the street it's on can be a little sketchy sometimes. Definitely a orth checking it out for the food but just walk quickly
author: Mallika G.

description:
I am a big fan of Ethipoan food and this place didn't disappoint me at all. I'd read the reviews here on Yelp prior to my visit and since it was favorably reviewed by some of my trusted Yelp friends, I decided that I'd come here for dinner with a colleague one evening.

We ordered the vegetarian combo and the beef tibs. I liked both quite a lot, but preferred the rich flavour of the beef tibs. 

Situated in the heart of the Tenderloin, I was expecting a run-down equipment but was actually surprised that the space was newly renovated and quite bright.
author: Uli B.

description: For 2 people, we had the veggie combo, the lamb ribs and special beef kitfo. Everything was super good, especially the 2 meat dishes. Also love the flavor of injera. We had plenty of leftover with those 3 orders. Would come back again!
author: Jessica C.

description: Well prepared, fresh and delicious vegetables and meat dishes. Staff was friendly and helpful! I have only a good feelings after this place!
author: Mary B.

description: Really great food at a reasonable price. Not ideal for dining in because the restaurant is quite small but otherwise it's solid.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Tiny but mighty eatery with superbly friendly service and delicious cheap eats. The place could probably only fit maybe 12-15 people comfortably, but this retains the high level of customer service: everyone makes sure your water glass is always filled, takes your order minutes after your sit down, and takes initiative to answer any questions you might have on any of their offerings. Service with a genuine smile, it's really a great and homey place to go with a small group or 1:1. 

Upon serving, they explain everything in detail, patiently answer questions, provide visiblity into what each item contains, so you're never left wondering what you might be getting in to if you're being adventurous. 

The dishes are beautiful whether you order meat or pure veggies, and the flavors are so powerful you are satisfied with just a slight amount of food. Plenty of injera to go around, and the best part of course is the one saturated with all the veggie and meat sauces. 

They also serve tiny squares of baklava warm, and the filling isn't bitter like most baklavas are (not overdone with walnuts).
author: Alison A.

description: Lovely food, lovely service! I wish they didn't get my vegan appetizer order mixed with the beef but other than that it was all really good. I totaly recomand them to anyone.
author: D P.

description: Great food! Small space with about 6-7 tables and very casual but the service and staff are extremely friendly!
author: Anthony L.

description: Whenever I'm traveling to the city I'm sure to stop by this place! It's walking distance to union square. The waitresses and cooks are really sweet. I'm vegan so it's nice coming here and knowing they do not cook with butter/eggs. My favorites are: gomen, telba, azifa, tima tima fit fit, and misir wot. The telba drink is really tasty. It's sweet from the honey. I enjoy this drink because it's healthy and  full of omegas. This is the best tima tima fit fit I've had. The chunks of injera are thick and the seasoning are spicy and tangy. This is the first place I ever had Ethiopian and I'm happy I did because now it's my favorite type of food! I love all of the spices and love they put in their food!
author: Joe G.

description: I ate here Ethiopian food for the first time in my life and enjoyed it very much. I ordered a dish (whose name I forget) with very tasty (and spicy) ground beef and some cheese and vegetables on the side, and most interesting - "injera", a kind of extremely flat, spongy and tasty bread which I've never tasted before and really enjoyed. The meal really filled me up, and the service was very friendly (I had no idea what to order, so they helped me choose. What I liked less about this restaurant was its tiny size (just 5 small tables, and I felt like I eas sitting in the kitchen) and its location - I did not feel very safe walking there in the evening.
author: Nadav H.

description:
Had lunch here with Divya

The owner is very friendly and took good care of use. We ordered multiple vegetarian dishes like wat, combo etc and they were all good. Specifically enjoyed misir wat as it was spicy and flavorful

Will go back again
author: Hemant D.

description:
My boyfriend took me to Tadu Ethiopian Resturant  on my vacation. I liked the food. We order Vegetable combination and Kitfo. It was finger licking. I tried some other Ethiopian Resturant in Oakland but I find Tadu's number one. As I am originally from Ethiopia, I know how our dishes taste like and I loved it and Enjoy it with a great customer service. It reminds me of mom's kitchen.     


I highly recommend Tadu Ethiopian Resturant and I'm definitely coming back!!
author: Mahlet A.

description: Came here my first night in San Francisco and it was amazing. My moms Vegan so we ordered a family style dish that included the vegetarian combo and something else and both were delicious! They gave us complementary baclava and we had spiced tea. The waitress and cook were so incredibly hospitable. This place had everything
author: Shelby B.

description: We had the the the Tibs Lamb and the assorted vegetable dishes. All was scrumptious, enjira was homemade. They let us test taste the Telba (flax seed with honey) drink which was refreshing and delicious. The space is small with only 6 tables and the decor is non existent. But the space is attractive and the staff incredibly nice, helpful and fast. The complimentary backlava and coffee were heart warming touches. Felt like we were in the their home.
author: Mike B.

description:
I'll start by saying to get the veggie combo and meat tibs if you've never had Ethiopian before. Very good way to get a nice experience with a variety of foods.

Overall, really, really good. We split the above among 3 people with sambusas and didn't finish all of the food. Service was quick and kind.

The lamb tibs were amazing. Perfect sear on the outside with juicy tender lamb on the inside, spiced perfectly. Be warned, this will have a little kick to it. The veggie plate was loaded with goodness, including some of the best collard greens I've ever eaten.

One thing I have to add for those who haven't spent much time in San Francisco - this place is located a little bit into Tenderloin. Tenderloin has a lot of homeless folks. If that will make you uncomfortable, Uber or Lyft in.
author: Dylan L.

description: This is by far the best Ethiopian food I've ever had, and I've tried a fair bit. The flavor is out of this world, the injera is legit, the special kitfo's got some special spice, the service is great. I just wish the place were bigger! Now that word has gotten out about Tadu, there's always a line out the door and not nearly enough tables for all the demand.
author: Marco C.

description:
Flavors: awesome. Deeper, more interesting, and I assume more authentic than the other Ethopian places I've been. Lots of good choices. We got the kitfo and the beef Tibs, and both were good, but the beef tibs were ESPECIALLY good...watch out, though, they're spicy; it'll kick your ass. I'm glad that the sever was ok with me getting up to serve myself several more waters. 

Seating: LIMITED. I wouldn't come here with more than a couple of people. Which kind of sucks, because it's a bit hard to do Ethopian takeout, AND Ethopian is more fun with more people....but they do takeout, and that would be the way to do it. Make sure to get extra Injera. 

Prices: Pretty good for ethopian, for sure! 

Location: Smack dab in a sketchy part of the tenderloin. Bummer.

Gastro the next day: Not so good. But I don't really care what my stomach says, I really like this place.
author: Chris S.

description:
Small and unassuming space, super friendly and kind staff, spectacular food.

We ordered three types of dishes between the three of us on a work trip - lamb tibs, beef banatu, and beef kitfo, served on the same platter of injera bread with an assortment of delicious and warm sides. 

Lamb tibs: Definitely the highlight of the experience, perfectly tender and juicy lambs and sauteed in spices, incredibly delicious and so much more than lamb chops I've had at fancy restaurants.
Beef kitfo: Since all three of us are relatively new to Ethiopian food, our kitfo was served half cooked and half rare. The flavor was amazing, spices in all the right places and not a care about its rareness - it was delicious.

Best food we've had on the entire San Francisco trip, and that's saying a lot! We polished off all of that with two side bowls of injera bread all during lunch time of a conference. Yes, it was that good.
author: Sharon Z.

description:
Delicious Ethiopian food! Went for the first time last night and it was fantastic. 

We ordered:
Lentil Sambusa - Little fried pocket of deliciousness. Very flavorful. Comes with a red spicy sauce that makes this appetizer special.
Vegetarian Combination- Lots of different sides. My favorite were the Misir Wot.
Minchet Abish Wot - Savory, spicy, really great with the injera.
Side of Shiro Wot - YUM. 

The restaurant is small and cozy. Casual vibe. The guy who waited on us, let us try the Shiro for free (and it was amazing). I highly suggest this restaurant if you like Ethiopian.

The only thing this restaurant is missing is a meat/veggie combo. Sometimes you just want a little of both :)
author: Jessica L.

description:
Got the veggie combination plate with beef tibs and shared it with two other people. It was my friends' first time trying Ethiopian, and I wanted them to come away with happy stomachs. The food was absolutely delicious, and the server was friendly and helpful. Not being very familiar with the menu, he helped explain the menu and suggested foods we could share as a group.

The place is a little small, but didn't feel crowded. When we arrived (around 6:30 on a Friday evening), nearly all of the tables were full but we luckily had no wait. Would definitely love to go again next time I'm in the area.
author: Tiffany S.

description: Good and authentic African food. The inside is tiny and they do not have too many options (compared to other african restaurant in general).
author: Christian D.

description:
For years, I have been telling friends and out-of-town visitors curious about where to find good Ethiopian food that in the Bay, your best bet is upper Telegraph in Oakland. This place opening--and on a mostly dormant block of the Tenderloin where some signs of life are badly needed--finally provides the San Francisco answer to that all-important query.

The story of this establishment's genesis also couldn't make me happier. Apparently the owner, who previously drove a taxicab, had had as much difficulty as I encountered in finding the answer when his taxicab passengers, learning of his country of origin, would press him for a good place in SF for Ethiopian. Apparently enough people asked that he finally decided he might as well open his own restaurant.

The results are spot on: The ingredients are fresh, the service is welcoming and attentive but in no way pushy, the prices are amazing, the portions are plentiful--two entrees easily satisfy three people--and last night I assuaged a lingering curiosity by bringing an Ethiopian friend from my French conversation group to give it a try. She was blown away. In her ensuing conversation in Amharic with the owner, we learned that the restaurant is named after his grandmother.

Please, please go here and help make it a success!
author: James D.

description: I am a big fan of Ethiopian food and there aren't many options in the city so I was glad to find Tadu on Yelp. It's a small hole in the wall restaurant with friendly staff. I shared the vegetarian platter and the lamb special with a friend. Both were excellent. I usually didn't like the meat dishes at other Ethiopian places because the texture seemed off, but the lamb is super tender and full of flavor. The veggie platter was also very good. We cleaned out plates. I did notice that the injira bread here is slightly thinner than other places but that just mean we don't stuff ourselves with as much bread :). Would definitely come back!
author: Alice W.

description:
One of my favorites, Tadu has never disappointed me. I have been there almost 20 times already and take anyone who visits San Francisco. Tucked away on a not so glamorous Tenderloin area, this is really a gem of a place. On some days you do have to wait as it's really a popular place and since the seating space is not much, there can be a bit of a wait, but it's always worth it.
The sambusa and the veggie combo are the best on the menu. The flavors are extremely well balanced. You must try the Ethiopian coffee as well! Injiras are soft and flavorful as well.
A total value for money!
author: Shishir S.

description:
Tadu is an incredibly tiny restaurant with 5-6 small tables. We went on a weekday evening and it was relatively empty....but with the positive reviews, we weren't sure how long the wait would be so we called ahead for a reservation! They were confused but obliged!

We started with the sambussa - a flaky pastry filled with meat or veggies - which was delicious. As our entree, we shared the veggie platter with lamb tibs. I love tibs! And these lamb tibs are great, especially with the deliciously sour injera.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Small clean diner style. 

Excellent food. 

Courteous staff. 

No liquor sold here FYI. 

Definitely would return. Locals and tourists frequent.
author: Simone M.

description: A cute and friendly place in the Tenderloin. The food is not as good as some places in Oakland (which has sooooo many Ethiopian restaurants), but don't get me wrong, the food is still very good. The food is healthier since some other Ethiopian places tend to be greasier, more friendly, more mom-and-pop, and the decor was from the owner's home in Ethiopia.
author: Wendy K.

description:
Delicious Ethiopian food and very friendly service! Space is limited though so not great for large groups. 

Protip: veggie combo + meat tibs = no regrets.
author: Anna X.

description:
Stopped by here for lunch this weekend before seeing a show at the Orpheum.

This is a small restaurant, with a clean, modern industrial look inside, with bold colors and nice art on the walls.

Friendly, helpful service, so even if you have no experience with Ethiopian food you should feel confident that you'll know what you're getting.

Great food. Bold flavors, both for the meats and the vegetables. The lamb tibs were my personal favorite - outstanding.

We had a table of four, and of course were looking for variety. We ordered a vegetarian combination along with the lamb tibs and the beef kitfo. That was plenty of food for the four of us. 

If you're in this area, you need to go support this restaurant.
author: Jason G.

description: Rolls on rolls on rolls of injera! A very comforting spot to get some authentic Ethiopian fare and escape the rigors of the TL for a bit. The veggie combo platter is very colorful and tasty and for $12, will certainly fill you up for the night. Very friendly and responsive service too, which warrants a return visit to Tadu soon!
author: Andy L.

description: Delicious authentic tasting Ethiopian food...Injer is made with Tef here and the spices are amazing!
author: Anant V.

description: Super friendly staff, the food is amazing. I would highly recommend this place to anyone who wants to explore new things. This was our first experience with Ethiopian food and like I said, it was amazing!
author: Jeremy G.

description: Un effing real. Thank you for the perfect meal - if you're looking for authentic delicious spicy flavorful Ethiopian food - this is your spot!!!
author: Andee G.

description:
I enjoyed the vegetarian combination and chicken tubs immensely. There wasn't a single item that I did not enjoy. It was flavorful and perfect for two people. 

It's super small but friendly and endearing
author: Rowen D.

description:
Food is great, and the quality is extremely high.
The value for the money is unreal, and once you'll get the good I am sure you'll agree.

I got the Lamb tibs: I wasn't hungry at all, but once the plate arrived the smell was so good I couldn't stop eating.

I loved the "bread" too.

It is a very different and fun night at a restaurant, more casual but with the same food quality you would get in a high end restaurant, but here at a tenth of the price.
author: Alessandro M.

description:
The food here is great...when they actually serve it to you and when you get what you ordered. I recently moved to the block by this restaurant. Looking for nearby places on Yelp, I was excited by the good reviews. And when I visited, I agreed.

Except the issues that have finally driven me to write this review were apparent from the first. We ordered two entrees, an appetizer, and an Etheopian beverage that sounded good. Our entrees were served in a timely enough manner and were delicious, but as we started to get full we realized neither our appetizer nor drink had made an appearance. It wasn't at all busy, mind you, but these things happen occasionally, after all. So we asked about them. We had to wait another 15 minutes for the drink, but our appetizer still was never served.

Oh, well, it's not as if we needed it. We got to go boxes and considered it part of the tip. But we agreed the service had issues--not only objectively, but also because of the attitudes of the staff, who gave me the impression we weren't actually welcome for no reason I could discern. But we figured it was a fluke.

Next time we ordered pick-up. When we arrived after the time we were notified our order was ready, they hadn't begun making it. We had to wait 20 minutes.

Next time we tried take out. They forgot the side dishes.

Next time we ordered pick-up online. They gave us the wrong meat, then refused to correct the problem.

I wish I could say this place was great, because the food is. Honestly, the fact that I love the food makes it worse, because it makes the feeling of disappointment more acute. But I've gotten to the point that it's just not worth the apathetic service and risk to both my time and money.
author: Reese H.

description:
Tadu is in the heart of the Tenderloin, so don't be surprised by the neighboring sights (and smells). But hey, the Tenderloin is also where you can get fantastic food of all kinds without spending a ton of money, and Tadu is no exception to this.

Once you find the restaurant and walk in, you'll notice that there isn't much in the way of decor (or seating). But don't be deceived by the sketchy surroundings and unassuming decor, the food is great and the staff are so friendly!

Our really nice server recommended that we split the lamb and chicken tibs and veggie platter between three people. He was really patient about explaining the various dishes and that the injera (Ethiopian sourdough bread with the consistency of a spongy crepe) was unlimited! To eat the meal, you rip the bread and use it to pick up various cooked meats and vegetables. It's a really social experience among friends, since everyone is reaching into and eating from the same communal platter. There was a wide variety of spices, textures, and flavors featured on the platter. Everything tasted pretty amazing, and we were very satisfied by the end of the meal. We were even more satisfied to discover that this very filling and enjoyable dinner cost us less than $15 each!

I probably never would have found this place if my friend hadn't insisted on "Ethiopian food" for dinner, but I'm glad he did, because the Yelp reviews don't lie -- this place is a hole-in-the-wall treasure!
author: Brittany C.

description:
We heard about this place a few times, read some reviews and finally checked it out last night. A really small restaurant, with only a few tables. It was slightly cramped, but well worth it. We had two dishes and a side of collard greens. It all came on one bigger plate on the traditional sponge bread, and it was too much food. Not too much in a bad way, but more than the two of us could eat. Very filling, great spice level, and really tasty. A little too tasty, because I kept eating after I was full and just got uncomfortably full. 
We chatted with the owner about Ethiopia and politics and had a great conversation. 
Overall, a good experience and we will be back for sure.
author: Bill L.

description: Not a lot of seats. Menu was confusing. I didn't know how to order a combo. The food was delicious, albeit greasy - both the meat and the veggies. Very tasty. The service was good.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Wow this food is good!

My partner and I went there for a Sunday lunch. The restaurant wasn't busy at all, which was probably for the best since they only have like seven tables.

It's also located in a rough part of town. It's in the heart of the Tenderloin, so be prepared for all the sights (and smells) that entails. 

With that out of the way, the food definitely made it worth the trip! We started with beef sambussas, which were fantastic. The meat had a delightful combination of spices, and the dipping sauce they came with was also spicy and full of flavor.

For our main course, we had an order of lamb tibs and another of beef tibs, served with injera. This is essentially a platter of heavily spiced meat, served with vegetables and cheese. Injera is the Ethiopian version of a crepe. You get as much as you can eat, and you also pick up the meat with it, as there is no silverware. We both thought the lamb tasted better than the beef (each was cooked in different spices), but both were awesome. 

We finished with Ethiopian coffee. I'm not much of a coffee drinker, and I still thought it was quite good.

Overall, every single thing we ate was delicious. The prices were all super cheap, and we walked out of Tadu with our stomachs feeling thoroughly stuffed. I will definitely be back!
author: Dan D.

description: Hands down the best Ethiopian I've had in the city. The vegetable dishes were all really flavorful and not heavy tasting at all. We got the eggplant, collared greens and cabbage, and devoured all three. The beef tips were well seasoned and juicy. We got take out from Tadu the next day because we liked everything so much.
author: Ivan M.

description: The best Ethiopian food I have had in SF. Small hole in the wall place, really good food, and excellent service.
author: Rinki K.

description: I've only been to one other Ethiopian restaurant in the city, and in glad I discovered another gem. The restaurant is small in size, but that matters not when the amount of food is large and hearty! The service was great, and our waiter was definitely a friendly soul. Since it was our first time here, he gave us some recommendations, and our group was happy with what we decided on. We pretty much ended up having an Ethiopian "Thanksigivng" feast! Everything from the different selection of wots, to the myriad of injera, topped off with an attentive and friendly server really made for our experience. We'll definitely be back! :)
author: Mark K.

description: My favorite Ethiopian food in SF. I'll go out of my way to eat here if I'm near Civic Center around lunch. Tadu is in the heart of the TL.
author: Owen S.

description: Delicious restaurant with lovely service.  The place is new, modern, and airy and the food was authentic.  It seemed a lighter to me than many other Ethiopian restaurants that we've tried, fresh and everything was really tasty.  We will be back!
author: Chris K.

description:
This was my first Ethiopian food experience and it was wonderful. Flavor in every bite, we got the Veg Combo and Lamb tibs. The lamb was tender and to die for. I didn't care for some of the veg servings in the combo, but the rest were good. Plenty of food for two people. 

What struck me most was how similar, yet different this cuisine was to some of the others. Definitely worth trying!
author: Val K.

description:
This place is small and cozy, and the staff pretty friendly. We ordered a veggie combo (recommended if you're unsure what you'd like - you get smaller portions of many of their full veggie plates), followed by Misir Wot (a lentils preparation). Their bread (injera) was soft and flavourful, and the veggie combo preparations were simple but well done. Being from India, we found the food similar in many ways, yet different in others. Two veggie plates sufficed for 3 hungry people. If that isn't enough, the prices are very reasonable too!

My only gripe would be that they played the same Ethiopian song on repeat while we were there, but even that was catchy to start with :)
author: Raghav G.

description:
If you're looking for a food adventure, this is it. 

Enjoyed a veggie combo to-go - perfect combination of spices, flavors and textures. You can tell a lot of time and effort was put into making the dish as delectable as it was.

This place is a small, local gem. Would give it 6 stars if I could.

Update:

Went back again with some friends and loved it just as much the second time. Lamb tibs are a must!
author: Linda X.

description:
Yelp rarely lets me down...and it did not tonight.
 
We had tickets for Book or Mormon, when I tried to find restaurants around the theatre from my home computer - they were a bunch in the tenderloin and a bunch of Union Square options none of them thrilled me.
 
I wasn't until I yelped NEAR the theatre on my phone that this little gem popped up. 5 Stars - heck yes I will try it.
 
This place is in a cruddy neighborhood, and the dining room is smaller than my living room , 20 people maybe (max)  and that would be a cozy bunch.
 
We asked if they had wine "no", then we asked if we could bring in a bottle "yes" - the we went across the street of a bottle and asked them for a wine opener "no" - SO when you buy the wine at the little bodega across the street - have them open it for you. The little fried apps everyone is talking about - YES, get them, in fact yet one lentil order and one beef order...We only had the beef, but I could have eaten all 3 by myself.
 
Then we split a vegetarian plate with some lamb tibs (maybe tips). It came with a HUGE side of injera bread that was nice a fluffy and a little bit sour. The platter had several items, a salad with 2 dips on top, then some collard greens, a potato/carrot/cabbage curry type thing, and 2 lentil dips - one yellow one orange, and of course the lamb with lots of onions and jalapenos - SPCY but great.
 
Service was very accommodating - allowing the wine, getting us cups for the wine, getting more chairs to help some people with a larger crowd, no rush to hurry and finish.
author: Amy W.

description:
I've never tasted Ethiopian food before so I thought I'd give it a try. This place does not disappoint!

I had the vegetarian combo, sambussa and some Ethiopian coffee. All highly recommended. 

The only word of advice I'd give is that this joint is located in the tenderloin region and is not the safest place in San Francisco. Still definitely give this place a go! Full stars on service, food and a cuisine you shouldn't miss!
author: Debjani B.

description:
A girl I was seeing really liked Ethiopian food, but I hadn't had it i around 7 years so I looked for a place near the Civic Center where I'd be meeting here. Found this place, it had crushingly good reviews and was a 5 minute walk.

It's a tiny 5 table restaurant, but they do table service and the place was clean and the wait staff are super friendly. We shared the veggie combo plate that comes with a little over everything vegetarian, and a grilled lamb dish. It was all served on a giant piece of Ethiopian bread, and with a basket of the same on the side. Other than plates and napkins, there are no utensils given (unless asked). You wrap the bread around the protein and shove it in your mother.

$30 got more than enough food for 2 people and we took half home. Great value, nice people.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Everything was pretty epic, not a single complaint.  

We had the veggie combo and all the dishes were delish.  It comes with the Kik Alicha, Misir Wot, Gomen and Alicha Tikil Gomen with sides of Azifa, buticha and salad. It's quite a feast on its own.  Highly recommend you go with this choice and get the best of all worlds.

I also had some of the Special Kifto (lean ground beef, onions and jalapeno sauteed with special spices and homemade butter) and it was great but not as amazing as the veggie dishes. 

Service was great, they are really friendly and fast.
author: Saminda W.

description:
Tadu was quite good, but didn't live up to the hype.  The food, service, and ambiance were all solid, but I wasn't blown away.

My friend and I shared the sambussas (the ground meat ones were better than the lentil ones), a veggie combo (the lentils and salad were quite tasty, but the collard greens and cabbage were a bit bland), and the lamb tibs (it was a bit dry and too spicy - I would have preferred a wetter preparation with more gravy).

The service was polite, friendly, and fast.

The restaurant itself was clean, well-lit, and welcoming.  I appreciated the sink outside the restroom for pre and post meal hand washing.  The Tenderloin location is, of course, less than desirable.

Overall, a good, but not amazing, meal.
author: Barnali D.

description: Super friendly staff, amazing food. This was our first time and won't be our last. We loved the veggie combo and lentil samusas
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Lamb tibs are awesome. Service is stellar too. Caleb is hands down one of the best servers ever. Really great guy. 

Limited seating. 

Love this place. Will definitely come back many times.
author: Ryan P.

description: Amazing! Come with an open mind, the server is very helpful and will make excellent recommendations!
author: Mckenzie P.

description:
I forget to eat Ethiopian as regularly as I should.  I freakin' love Ethiopian food.  

There is something about the spongy bread, the beautiful colors and the amazing range of flavors that just does it for me.  While staying in San Francisco, I looked up vegan-friendly places to eat within walking distance to my hotel in the Tenderloin.  Tadu came up and I kept bugging my companion to go there - when we did, we were not disappointed.  

Like many restaurants in the Tenderloin, it's small.  It was completely packed with a diverse crowd when we came in and we got seated basically in the back hallway.  I didn't care.  The food was yummy (vegetarian platter), the service was prompt and friendly and the bread seemed unlimited...don't quote me on that, but we had plenty! I want to go back...I may have left my heart in San Francisco!
author: Bijana K.

description:
Tiny spot in the 'loin. We picked up our comestibles and headed home. 

I ordered the veggie platter. So solid, great service, affordable. Get your injera on, and prepare for a carb coma. Yoooomeeeee!
author: Gabriela W.

description:
So the people here are super nice, but ZOMG SPICY! Seriously! We told our waiter we didn't like very spicy food, so he helped us order the "mildest" items. Holy crap! Mild in Ethiopia must be 400,000 on the Scoville scale. I'm always one to finish my meal, even if it isn't great, but none of us (there were 4 - mostly latinas) could tolerate the spice. After 2 bites, we had them box up our meals & we handed it to the homeless guy outside (after providing warning about the spice). I'm surprised other reviewers haven't had the same problem - maybe the seemingly nice waiter was jerking our chain? I have no idea.

On a side note, this is not in the best area. If you're an out-of-towner, just be wary coming here at night. Also, there's very limited seating inside.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
One of the best restaurants in San Francisco ! Very authentic! Full of tastes and colors!
Will be back soon .. Highly recommend !
author: Michael J.

description: My girls told me I had to give them five stars! My picky 5 yr old ate a ton of chicken tibs and my 7 yr old love the special kitfo.
author: Nhieu w.

description:
I'm originally from Ethiopia, I know how the real Ethiopian foods tastes like and I been looking for a great Ethiopian restaurant here in SF.. Tadu woooooooooow I love everything from the menu. I'm a Kitfo lover and I don't believe some restaurant's spice because I know the real Ethiopian spice taste but Tadu Kitfo is the best like homemade. 

Since my first day at Tadu I never disappointed cause I found everything always the same!!!

I highly recommended Tadu for who are looking for the real Ethiopian restaurant.
author: Gize A.

description: Great food, it's one of the best restaurant in San Francisco I had so far really delicious I will definitely will recommend to anyone about Tadu Ethiopian kitchen .
author: Tomer B.

description: Very cute little place on a pretty hectic block of the Tenderloin. Had the veggie combo and the lamb tibs. Both were quite good for SF, though there are places in Oakland (Enssaro especially) that are better.
author: Erica W.

description: Very nice customer service.  Fresh food I usually order the misir wot(split lentils with berbere, onions, garlic, spicy hot).  Always generous portions comes with side salad and some kind of stewed cabbage and injera.  Delicious with enough leftover for the next day.
author: Sina T.

description: The vegetarian combo was incredible- so much flavor and just a little bit of everything.
author: Emily C.

description:
The restaurant is small, but nice. It's clean and not overcrowded, but is very busy. The service was great, except that one of the drinks came out after we'd finished the meal. But he apologized for it and explained that it took a bit longer to make. 

We ordered the Sambussa, and multiple veggie combos. The Sambussa with lentils was ok. I definitely wouldn't order it again. The injeera was great, but the rest of the veggie platter was also just "ok". There isn't a punch of flavor, and the seasoning wasn't well-balanced. There was far too much tumeric, not cooked properly, and a few of us walked away with yellow nails. 

It wasn't a bad dish, but we also made sure not to end the night on the taste from Tadu. Based on location, convenience, and food, my next craving for Ethiopian will be satisfied by Sheba.
author: Dimple B.

description: Had lunch here yesterday we ordered lamb chicken and veg platter the flavors were excellent, we all commented that it woke up our taste buds.  The service was very gracious and attentive, definitely will be back.
author: Kent P.

description: This is my favourite place for Ethiopian food. The lamb was extremely well spiced and the vegetable sides were all delicious. The restaurant has really friendly staff. The main differentiator is that food comes with unlimited injera. The only downside is that the place has quite limited seating.
author: James S.

description: The food is delicious, super friendly staff & great service, and the portions were such that I had a full lunch off the leftovers! We got the veggie combo, LENTIL SAMBUSSA (SOO GOOD) and beef tibs for 2 people. It was wayy plenty of food. And for a great price :D if you call like 15 mins early, they can try to hold you a table which would probably be worth the effort cuz its a verryy cozy place, only like 5 or 6 tables and no space to wait for a table to free up inside so you might have to wait outside in the grimey TL streets which is known to rob you of your appetite.
author: Sara C.

description:
Decor: 4/5
-VERY limited seating
-has incense sticks placed near the tables on the steel beams

Service: 5/5
-very welcoming and homey, our orders were taken at the table and served to the table

Food: 5/5
-First time trying Ethiopian and I'm blown away at how delicious the dishes were.
-I ordered the vegetarian combo and the beef tibs. Addicting & Wow. Two word sums up the beef tibs. Excellent flavors and spices for the beef tids. I didn't know exactly what the vegetarian combination consisted of however each side did not disappoint my adventurous taste buds
-The collard greens, lentils and chickpeas from the vegetarian dish were all great as well.
author: P H.

description:
I liked it!

Pros: The food had tons of flavor and it was easy to go carb free. There was enough protein that I was full for a long time. Portion size really generous, couldn't even finish everything.

Cons: Had no idea what i was ordering, wish the menu had more explanations, also lots of flies inside.
author: desert g.

description: The best Ethiopian food I have had in the US. The chicken tibs here is amazing and would totally recommend ordering it with the veggie combo .
author: Anand S.

description:
Oakland and Berkeley have long bested San Francisco when it comes to quantity and quality of Ethiopian/Eritrean food, but with the recent opening of Tadu, the scales may finally be tipping. This was the best Ethiopian meal I've had in SF. 

The veggie combo and chicken tibs tasted so fresh and full of flavor. The staff was friendly. The prices were reasonable. And with its high ceilings, vibrant paint and exposed steel beams, the small seating area felt relaxed and unimposing.

Ask for the not-so-spicy "spicy sauce," a traditional housemade awaze sauce that complements the flavors if you need a little something extra.
author: Tim B.

description:
Good Ethiopian food at good prices and good service - not much more to ask for (maybe nicer location?). It's cozy and clearly owner operated day to day with that small business charm.

We just missed getting an available table when we walked in and had to wait 20 or so minutes but it was worth it. The owner offered us for free the beef sambussa appetizer as we waited which was very nice of him and didn't hurt that it tasted great.

As its Ethiopian food, you order items that are placed on a communal thin sponge like bread that has a little sourdough tang to it. We got the lamb ribs and vegetarian combo. Both were great and more than enough to fill the two of us.

The Telba drink was also great. It's flaxseed and honey and ends up tasting like a sweet healthy breakfast.
author: Victor W.

description:
This little joint in the Tenderloin has some tasty tasty food. Halfway through our meal there were people outside waiting for one of the half-dozen tables--I told the guy at the register they'd have to move to a larger location soon, and they said they were working on it.

Anyhow! This place serves the standard Ethiopian fare, with a few extras you don't often see: sambusas, kinche (bulgur wheat) as well as injera, and a few special dishes. I got the veggie combo and everything was mighty tasty. The injera was rich, spongy, and just the right amount of sour. I also got a glass of telba, a drink made with flax seeds that you have to try to appreciate. It's rich and yummy.
author: Nik G.

description:
One of the best Ethiopian restaurants we have been to anywhere. A real standout in San Francisco. 

The owners are some of the kindest and warmest people you will ever meet. Outstanding service too.
author: Harry A.

description:
Went here after a Giants game. So glad I did. Walking there takes you along some shady zones but it's worth the venture.
