The place is small. One 4 top and five 2 person tables. The menu is pretty basic, which I think makes sense for a smaller place. I had the special kitfo and peas. Wow, the kitfo was so flavorful. The recipes sits well above many other places I've been. The peas were lightly flavored and their creaminess matched the kitfo well.
author: Dave S.

description:
Kitfo special and gomen besega are my jam and they definitely delivered here! The spices and ghee were so indulgent against the tender meat and stewed greens. And who doesn't love the primitive nature of eating sans utensils? Very interactive.

One recommendation is to go raw with the kitfo--its like steak tartare but a million times better sopped up with tart injere. 

So glad to find another good ethiopian place a hop and skip away from home.
author: Katie O.

description: Tadu is the most delicious Ethiopian in the Bay Area!! The owner is super nice and so welcoming to everyone. I feel right at home. And their spices area incredible omg! Delicious!!
author: Katie W.

description:
A hole in the wall. 
My boyfriend and I first discovered this place while cat sitting for a friend in the tenderloin. We were hungry & decided to give it a shot since neither of us had tried Ethiopian food. We ordered the vegetarian combo and the vegetable melody.  I thought it was really fun to eat with my hands since I had never usually done that with food at a restaurant. I feel it brought me in tune with my meal. (Oh yeah, They have a sink next to the restroom to wash off the city grime and bus germs. I like to see who washes and who eats with dirty hands) 

I have to say it's been a few months since first discovering this place. We go back once a week to once every two weeks, we've become regulars and it's really nice because they give amazing service and they remember you and sometimes throw in a complementary baklava. 

I've tried other places in the Bay Area and they just don't compare to tadu. It's always worth the 10 min commute just to eat some warm, satisfying Ethiopian food made with love! (All the cooks are very sweet) 

It's affordable. Bring a date or your family or work colleague here. They will love it. Just remember to wash your hands!
author: Emmy M.

description: Food was good but not authentic flavor wise. Seems to have been tweaked for American palates. For example kitfo should be similar to beef tartare but was served well done. Also tibs had spices but no berbere, onions subbed for shallots, and no bell peppers. Nice introduction to ethiopian food just be open minded because the taste will be off if you are used to real ethio food.
author: Lillian H.

description:
For catering, they really hooked it up.

I had a large order that had to suit all sorts of dietary needs. They took it all in stride, suggested a fabulous menu of items and made sure there was plenty for everyone.

There were so many compliments on the food that day that it made me wish I cooked it. But I can't cook this good. 

If you have tons of hungry people to feed, you can't go wrong with Tadu. Definitely doing it again!
author: Loli L.

description:
I don't normally write reviews but I felt compelled to after my dinner there tonight.  I left asking myself why haven't eaten Ethiopian food before? Simply put, this was one of the best meals I've had here and very reasonably priced. 

I ordered the lamb tib and a glass of telba. The lamb is cooked perfectly, sautéed with onions and grilled jalapeños on top of injera and just enough spiciness to make you break into a mild sweat. A basket of injera is also provided. It comes with a very flavorful salad and yellow split peas which accompanies the lamb extremely well. The telba reminds me of a Taiwanese roasted peanut and rice drink. It was so good that I was saddened when it appeared I was the only one drinking it when I looked around. 

The place is a little small so large parties may be difficult to accommodate. I do want to add to other tourists that it's in the tenderloin which starts looking like the cast of thunderdome stopped by when it gets dark.  But if you're looking for a great dinner that's reasonably priced, don't miss this place.  I'll certainly be back.
author: John Y.

description: Wow, Tadu has stolen my heart. This restaurant is the real deal making their injera with teff and having huge vegan feasts. The owner was so kind to give us a free appetizer because we had to wait for a table which we didn't mind at all but how nice! We were going to each order the vegan feast but he suggested we order two to share and then add sides that we like. Sooooo good. Can't wait to go back. Thank you Tadu!!
author: Eryn L.

description:
This was our first time trying out Ethiopian food. And we really loved it! 

This is a newly opened restaurant in the Tenderloin (my hood!). It's literally one block from our apt. Love the bright colors and Ethiopian art. It's a very small place. Probably fit 12-16 people. There is a table or two outside also. But service was fast and friendly so prob won't have to wait that much (for lunch anyway, when we went). 

I ordered the Tibs with lamb and hubs ordered the vegetarian combo. All served on top of injera bread. I think this was best way to introduce ourselves to the cuisine: one meat and assortment of veggies. So you eat with your hands, and use injera bread to pick up the dishes. A really fun experience and the delicious food made it even better. The food reminded me of various Mediterranean and even Carribean dishes (the sambusa appetizer esp), so yummy.

I think this place will be really popular, if not already. Especially to vegetarians/vegans, they have a lot of options. So glad we live close by because we will be back very soon, and often. Great value also, good prices.
author: Vol T.

description: I'm an Ethiopian who misses home cooking. Tadu is the closest thing to home cooking you can find anywhere. The food is delicious and there's a huge portion to share with friends! The owner and the people that work there are so nice and friendly. I feel like I'm at home everytime I eat at Tadu. Can't recommend it enough!
author: Abenezer M.

description:
Very solid Ethiopian food tucked away in a pretty unexpecting place. I haven't really experienced Ethiopian food in the Bay Area, so I can't be sure how it compares, but their vegetarian options are solid. Exactly how Ethiopian food should taste. 

I'm a huge fan of Ethiopian food, but I came with two other friends who had never had Ethiopian food before. If you've tried to bring people to Ethiopian food for the first time, you should know that there is some tip-toeing involved for the pickier eaters. Noticing this, the owner (or a worker, I think) came by at the beginning of our meal and explained in very endearing terms the history of Ethiopian food. It was such a delightful but brief conversation, and had me laughing about how open the staff really was to anyone trying their food. 

Lovely place, and a great first entry to Ethiopian food for those who have been hesitant to try it! This is no frills - just authenticity.
author: Ruoxi Y.

description: Brought my boyfriend here because he always begs me to make him Habesha food but lord knows it's an effort. I love love love coming here it's super fast, they remember us lol, and any time I ask him what he's in the mood for, it's usually Tadu.
author: Tattiana B.

description: I love the food and people here. They are very nice and even though the place is a bit old and in an awkward part of the city, place seems clean and food is sooooo good.
author: Yeliz U.

description: This place is a gem! The food is great and authentic at an exceptionally low price. The portions were huge and our server was extremely nice!!
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Nice little ethiopian spot here in the city. Me and my three friends had Kitfo, lamb tibs and Shiro. Everything taste delicious and very authentic. 
Kale Ab our waiter was extremely nice. We will definitely  be back here. 
Go check it yelpers !!!!
author: Maranatha D.

description: Great food, great service.  I ended up getting my food to go because it was so crowded inside.  Area is very undesirable but don't let that keep you from experiencing the great food Tadu has to offer!
author: Jeff F.

description: I've definitely gotten soft living in Honolulu enough so that I was intimidated by the neighborhood and a little uneasy when we arrived at the restaurant and had to wait outside for a table. Only three people running he restaurant and they were hustling. No one to really man the front of the place but since he place is tiny you can see the entire restaurant and kitchen from the front. Anyhow service is fast and friendly and food comes out quick. So we got a table pretty quickly.  But no one taking names. You just wait until a table opens up and seat yourself. The place is small and bare bones but clean and bright. Somehow seems more legit than the other Ethiopian place we were considering which serves brunch and burgers etc. but maybe that's regular Ethiopian fare too? Anyhow the food was worth waiting and delicious and I miss Ethiopian food very much. Despite being busy the service was friendly and warm and food came out quick hot and delicious. Got the veggie combo and the chicken tibs and ate it all. It was on the spicy side so I guess my punk status when it comes to spice has been solidified. What happened to me? Anyhow the hub almost ate a big old slice of jalapeño from the tibs bc he thought it was a bell pepper. I saved his life before he bit into it like a good wife. It was plenty of food including he basket of injera that accompanied it. We both resolved to try the one Ethiopian restaurant in Honolulu again even though we were disappointed he first time. Bc tadu reminded us how much we looooooove this cuisine. We decided even more than North Indian food. But since we soft now we ubered it there and back. (Were we ever not soft?) I think since even ny was so safe before we left we just can handle any non gentrified areas anymore. Punks. That's us.
author: Jannet L.

description: This place is TINY. Definitely get here early if you want a table. There's only 2 workers here, the server/cashier and cook. Service is kind of slow, so make sure you have plenty of time. We ordered the veggie combo, chicken tib, beef banatu, and lamb tib. I didn't try the lamb, since I'm not a big fan, but everything else was great. This was more than enough for a party of 4.
author: Lisa T.

description:
This place doesn't need ANOTHER 5 star rating. It's the best Ethiopian food in San Francisco. I also enjoy Zeni's in San Jose (I used to live in Palo Alto and that was my go-to). 

This place is like 4 blocks from my apartment. I've tried other Ethiopian places in SF because it's my favorite cuisine, but honestly theres no reason to ever go anywhere else. The only con is that its very small, but I've never had to wait for a table. I've gotten takeout there before and that worked out well too. They gave me so much injera with my takeout and the portions were huge - I order a meat dish and a veggie side and then my boyfriend and i have dinner and breakfast. Ethiopian for breakfast sounds weird but don't knock it until you try it!
author: Zareen A.

description:
I love Ethiopian food and while this still doesn't beat Ethiopia restaurant $7 all you can eat buffet in Berkeley in terms of value and taste, it is local and has a nice ambiance, and good service. The place is very colorful and a lot of the clients were Ethiopian. This is good, I tend to take that as an auspicious sign when i see natives eating at an ethnic food place. It confirms authenticity. The music was rocking, too bad I don't understand amharic. Everything was new, clean and well organized.

I ordered the vegetarian combo, and it came with a few cold veggie sides that were amazing and unfortunately like most things on their menu difficult to pronounce. Nice to know that if you aren't a fan of injera you can order their rice (Kinche) or even wheat or sourdough bread instead. You also have the option at a premium to get your injera gluten free. 

The best part about this place is the service, when the waitress wasn't busy catering to the local TL vagabonds wandering in for napkins, she was taking orders/payments, refilling the water, and bread.  Though I declined more injera, she was pretty insistant I take another refill, very sweet. Nothing on that plate disappointed, the injera was cold and a bit dry but other than that the food really hit the spot. I couldn't finish it all and took half of the plate home. It made for a great breakfast the next morning. The  Vegetarian combo cost $13 excluding tip so it isn't something to eat every day. I actually think it is pricier than Moya on 9th street. They have been open for 3 weeks and I'm surprised I'm the first review. Please offer a lunch buffet or cheaper lunch menu like Moya does with different lunch/dinner menus and you will have me hooked!
author: Onika C.

description: Holy shit. Go here. End of story. Get the vegetarian combo and lamb tibs for 2 people.
author: Tim W.

description:
I love pretty much everything about this place, except for its location and tinyness. Because it's a popular spot and so small, you kind of have to wait outside until your name is called and it's definitely in the heart of the tenderloin, which can be a bit uncomfortable at times.

The people who work here are so, so nice and friendly and are super helpful with your ordering. They'll make suggestions based on what you want and you should definitely just go with what they suggest!

We got the veggie combo, kitfo and chicken for 4 people, and it was plenty of food. Came out to about $13/person. 

My favorite was the lentils and the kitfo, while my group loved the chicken. 

It's also BYOB, or at least we saw others with their own wine and we brought in beers to drink and they didn't stop us.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Some pretty solid Ethiopian food in one of the shadiest neighborhoods in town. I got dropped off in an uber right outside this restaurant and there was a swarm of homeless people all around me. Be safe in this area, but once you get inside the restaurant, you don't feel like you're in the Tenderloin anymore. It's a small, homely place with just a few tables and chairs.

Their menu has all the regular Ethiopian dishes but the thing I liked most about this place was that you could get their dishes as side dishes instead of the full dinner portion. The beauty of Ethiopian food is that you get to try a lot of dishes with the delicious injera so having the option of getting multiple small dishes was a huge plus for me! The veggie combo is also a great choice for those looking to get a small taste of a variety of their different vegetarian options.

This place is very reasonably priced and their staff is extremely friendly. I will definitely be back again!
author: Malika R.

description: Good quick service. My boyfriend and I walked in and there was only one other person in the restaurant. The waitress was very attentive and gave her recommendations when I asked. Very friendly. Checked up on us to make sure things were alright. This is my second time eating Ethiopian food and it did not disappoint. I Would recommend this place to friends.
author: Milinda A.

description:
I found this place when walking to my usual spot for Ethiopian was too far out of my way. I'm glad I did! I cannot recommend Tadu enough. What a gem. 

The menu here is pretty much the menu from any Ethiopian place. Thats' not a knock at all, it's just that there were no real surprises. I got my usual veggie combo. The server (and owner?) was quiet but very nice. When he brought the spicy sauce and asked if I liked some, he lit up a bit and went back to get some spicy powder, which he proceeded to add directly to my plate. He explained the two things I didn't recognize (and couldn't tell you what they were now).

I'm looking forward to my next trip to SF for Tadu!
author: Damon T.

description: Awesome Ethiopian food! We always order the veggie comb with two meat additions. Always delicious and the customer service is always friendly. We can't wait for the new location to open up
author: Raina W.

description:
I got the chicken tibs and it did not disappoint! The meal came with injera, chicken, salad, lentils, and more injera on the side. Ethiopian food is made to eat with your hands, but alas I resorted to using a fork. 

Service was really nice and fairly quick. The portion size was quite generous (not to mention you can always eat a lot of injera). For people not familiar with Ethiopian food, it's actually surprisingly similar to Indian food in taste. Injera is a spongy bread like side that's soft in texture. 

The price was also great- $9.95 for a delicious, filling meal! =]
author: Aimee Z.

description:
Come here - you will not be disappointed. We ordered a veggie combination with lamb tibs and the flavors were incredible! 

The prices are affordable and the plates are massive. The owners and staff members are kind, generous and can help you pick a dish you will love. In an age of fast food and individualized meals we rarely sit down and share a plate. The Ethiopian style of eating left us feeling satisfied, and more closely bonded - there is something deeply satisfying about sharing food. TADU is a great place to split dishes and share together. It is an experience...you will not forget...in a good way.
author: Anna J.

description:
They roast their own coffee beans.  Really good Ethiopian coffee.

I enjoyed their Vege Platter.  Owner was also kind enough to allow us to split the Kitfo into a Special and Normal Kitfo.

Solid place.  I'll be back!
author: Koalie W.

description:
Nice and healthy food. Have vegan/vegetarian options. We initially ordered one Sambussa, but later ordered 4 more. It's awesome. I ordered one vegetarian combo. It's good. My friends ordered one chicken and lamb tibs. There ordered it again for second time. It's great.

One note: all the food includes salad, so don't order salad separately.
author: Ashwin Kumar N.

description: Great food, quick service reasonable price.  I will be back. Only negative is the amount of homeless on the street near the restaurant. So sad.
author: Brian L.

description:
Great food, warm staff, super cheap! 

We had Chicken tibs, Veggie combo with Injeras.. The chicken was sooo good! I can still taste it, a must must have! They also carry Ethiopian coffee - highly recommended! I may sound crazy but I also highly appreciate them giving wet wipes post food, with all that finger licking chicken and spicy lentil I needed that! 

Why 4/5 then? coz I've had better yellow lentil and cabbage.
author: Nupur K.

description:
Look, imma drop some knowledge on you: your experience in an Ethiopian restaurant depends on who does the ordering. If you or anyone in your party does the ordering, you fail. If you work with either an experienced waiter, or better yet the proprietor, tell him what you like, and HE figures out your order for you, you gonna eat a lot of win. Figuring out the best guy to order from can be a little bit of a conversation, but you just smile and roll with it and if the proprietor jumps in ain't nobody gonna be offended.

Boom, there you go.

The food here is super clean, well prepared, deliciously spiced, served fast (in my experiences), and an extremely good deal. The injera is made from real tef and has that great slightly sour taste. Both the meat and veg options are great here - you can't go wrong. The guy running it is a friendly bloke. Just talk about what kind of food you like and ask him how much he suggests. He'll mix it up and you won't be completely sure what all you're paying for and it will still be a great deal.

There's a reason this place has only one 1-star and 2-star reviews - either it's because people be crazy, or they're still ironing out a couple service issues. Look when you show up at a popular, small joint, and you're not the first one there, you need to get your patient on. When you eat Ethiopian it's not just the food that's part of the cultural experience - you have to jump into the whole interaction, from getting seated to ordering to enjoying your meal.
author: David K.

description: This place is saving my life.  It's the first Ethiopian restaurant I've found in the city that delivers, so that's a game changer right there.  On top of that it's really, really good.  I'm going to be a regular.
author: Laura W.

description:
Great Ethiopian food!  

Had the ground beef with spices...and a lot of spice they have! It is pretty spicy...you might want to get some vegetarian options as well.  The vegetarian platter is a very good pick for that.  We ordered two meals and it fed 4 people.  So you can definitely eat for cheap here. 

I would suggest washing your hands before you eat, they don't do silverware.  Like classic Ethiopian food you eat with your hands by scooping up the food with the sour dough pancake stuff. 

The coffee is excellent as well.  I suggest ordering the Ethiopian Coffee to go with your email. 

Parking may be a pain....there isn't a parking lot so you may have to park out there in street possibly in the sketch area. So...plan accordingly.
author: Jen L.

description: The food was amazing.  Fast service.  They don't serve alcohol but you can go down the street and bring your alcohol and they are cool about that.
author: Orlando G.

description: Just Ok. Nothing exceptional or special. overall descent.
author: Monica R B.

description:
It's my first time try this kind of food and it's was so good the waitress is so nice and the service great 
Very good place I will for sure come back here
author: Cheny C.

description: Fantastic food!  Very casual, and your can bring your own wine/beer. Highly recommended!
author: Leah L.

description: Very delicious. Area was shady but food was really good. Sometimes you have to go the distance to find great food.
author: Meron G.

description: Never had Ethiopian food before but this was a very good first impression! Very quick, attentive service. Not too big of a fan of the injera (the bread they serve with it) but that's just personal preference
author: Daniel H.

description:
Can NOT stop raving about this place to everyone! Tadu was my first experience with Ethiopian food, and it was everything I had hoped it would be, and more. Robust and strong flavors, distinct and varied textures and ingredients, and such an experience. It sets the bar high for future chances I'll have to eat Ethiopian food.

For starters, we got the Sambussa, which feels a bit like Ethiopian empanadas--meat filling inside a flaky pastry dough. Delicious.

Mains included the veggie combo, the Kitfo (beef, medium rare), and the lamb tibs. Everything was amazing; the kitfo and the lamb tibs were my favorite, thought they taste completely different from one another. We ordered 3 things for three people and we were so stuffed at the end of our meal. Even though portions may not look formidable, you'll fill up pretty quickly. I suspect this is because you eat everything with a bit of their tasty injera bread.

The service is warm, friendly, and super attentive, as I've come to expect from authentic, family-run restaurants. Can't wait to make a return trip :)
author: Chrystal Z.

description: Awesome place in a controversial neighborhood. The food is so o tasty and the stuff is super friendly and helpful.
author: Julie R.

description:
I came here on whim with someone since the near by hot pot place had a 1-2hr wait. Not that this place really needs yet another positive review, but 6/5 I'll be back. Two pretty large guys came no where close to finishing our plate and our minds were blown by the spicing and flavor. Granted, I've never had Ethiopian before, but it's going to be hard to beat Tadu. 

The place is small, but don't let that change your mind; it's totally worth the slightly cramped tables. When we walked in we gave the place a quick look around and audibly wondered what the table next to us was eating. They chimed in and said, literally, "We have no idea". We just asked for what they were having and weren't disappointed. 

I believe we had the lamb, but as an avid meat eater but vegetarian dater, I wouldn't have been the least bit disappointed to eat full-veg here.
author: Alex R.

description:
Fantastic service and awesome food. If you can handle spices and don't mind eating with your hands: Tadu is THE place to come.
No alcoholic beverages available but bringing your own is fine and there used to not have any corkage fee.
Place is small so big groups will have a hard time. Only one or two spots for 4 ppl. The rest is small and good for 2 or 3 at most.
author: Hugo C.

description:
12/30/2015

This place gave me another appreciation and renewed love for Ethiopian food. 

Great ownership! Sambussa was great. Lamb tips and injera and the veggie combo was just made to perfection.
author: Hussam S.

description: Delicious spot for Ethiopian cuisine! The food and staff are phenomenal. So kind and extremely attentive. Not to mention, their dessert is amazing. I will definitely be back!
author: Marissa M.

description:
Delicious, affordable, friendly, quick.

Arrived at 7:30 on a weekday, waited 20 minutes. Would have waited an hour if necessary: this food is awesome. 

The two of us shared beef sampusas, veggie combo, lamb tibs, and an order of baklava. More than enough food for two people.
author: Josh W.

description: Best Ethiopian food in town hands down! Ordered ribs goden, veggie combo, regular kitfo and vegetarian banatu. The owner was so incredibly nice, greeted us so warnly and even offered us a complimentary traditional Ethiopian tea. I have had a lot of Ethiopian food in the bay area, but his place is the most authentic, fresh and delicious. I can't wait to come back the again!!!!
author: Emnet W.

description: My first time trying Ethiopian and I was very pleasantly surprised! I'm, I would say, moderately adventurous in my tastes and my husband is more so and wanted to go here. We had the veg platter and he added kifto that was medium rare, probably more on the rare side. It was awesome. The injera was very good. Service was pleasant and nice to give us directions on where to go with the menu/questions. We didn't wait long even though they were insanely busy. Neighborhood is of course a bit sketch being in the center of the tenderloin but it's worth it!
author: Kelsey S.

description: The most flavorful food you can eat for 10 bucks per entree. Really nice, cozy hole in the wall with great personal service. We ordered two vegetarian platters amongst the three of us and it came with this soft crepe like bread (like spa soft Indian dosa). It went very well with the curries and vegetables that came on top of the bread. Everything was cooked and spiced to the right degree. Deceptively filling. I am sure the meat must be good too but I can only speak to the vegetarian.
author: Raj S.

description: This place was a goddamn religious culinary experience. It was AMAZING. Got sambusas, a combo platter, and baklava, and it blew my mind. I had eaten before coming, but couldn't stop myself from eating until I couldn't anymore. 13/10 would go again.
author: Alex P.

description: This place was awesome.  A tiny hole in the wall, with the friendliest servers.  The food was phenomenal.  We had the lamb tibs and vegetarian combo platter, perfect for 2 to share.  And to start, we got the delicious ground beef sambussa.  Super fast oto!
author: Al W.

description: Great Ethiopian restaurant in San Francisco! Very creative dishes and not all pureed baby-food type like most other Ethiopian places. Not much seating inside, so sometimes there is a line. Located in the scary Tenderloin, so if you make it in alive, it's worth it.
author: Peter K.

description: Amazing food and extremely nice restaurant employees!!! They define what good customer service is and Ahliyas (hope I spelled that right), who I think is the manager/owner, was so nice to my kind of unruly, picky daughter and brought a couple dishes to our table that his daughter would eat to help us out in enjoying our dinner in hopes of her eating it and also enjoying her time. LOVE LOVE LOVE that he and staff went he extra mile to do that as they saw us struggling to introduce her new foods. Definitely going here again with or without my family hahaha!! Great food and people! Wish I took a picture of the yummy lentils!
author: Clarissa M.

description:
Delicious!

The food is actually quite simple, but it is also quite tasty.
The prices are fair.
The service was a bit slow, but that did not make the food any less wonderful.
author: Ted Q.

description: Pretty decent Ethiopian.  It's very small in there and they had to play Tetris with the tables.  The staff were very nice though.  I was not a fan of the eggplant.  It was just like a stir fry that you attempt at home but it doesn't turn our right.  Everything else I ate was pretty standard Ethiopian fare that you expect in the US - lentils, cabbage, collard greens, all solid.  Vegetarian options are good.
author: Jess C.

description:
San Francisco has a lack of decent Ethiopian food so I was excited to try Tadu when it first opened. We ordered a bunch of veggie dishes and all gluten free injera. I would say the quality here is much better than Moya, but not as good as Cafe Colucci in Oakland.

Gluten free notes: They have gluten free injera $3 however I got very, very sick after eating here. Unsure what the issue was - maybe someone accidentally added regular injera? Anyhow, not worth the risk for me to go back. Try Cafe Colucci in Oakland instead.
author: Shannon Z.

description: So delicious!! It's so awesome to have a great Ethiopian place near my house. They are always so friendly and accommodating. Having the gluten free injera means my boyfriend and I can both enjoy their amazing food without worry! Thank you Tadu!
author: Robin A.

description: This is my first time here. I haven't had the opportunity yet to try many of their dishes. However, I will be returning to try others items on the menu. I had the kifto - AMAZING!  It was perfectly spiced with flavor and heat. I'm dining alone, so there were leftovers. The place is very small with only 6 tables. I came at 1:00 and didn't have to wait. Service was fast and the server was nice and polite.
author: Marsha K.

description: Best Ethiopian I've had anywhere, though I can't claim my palate is well established for that cuisine. This place is also sparkling clean and has great service, rarities in its part of the city.
author: David S.

description:
Delicious. Absolutely perfect. 
Beef sambusas (first time trying these but so tasty)
Veggie combo (my Ethiopian food usual, very fresh and flavorful)
Kind staff 
Clean everywhere
Cozy, wouldn't recommend for a large group espesh on a busy night. 
I walked 35 minutes to get here after Bay to Breakers run. So worth it.
author: Katie R.

description: Caution! Spicy and very delicious! Food made out of good quality products. Place is neat and clean. Authentic experience guaranteed! :)
author: Vic B.

description: Delicious food, great service. Very reasonable prices for the city. Best Ethiopian food I had in the Bay Area for a long time. Defiantly coming back and try a few more dishes.
author: Sergio L.

description:
I enjoyed my meal and service. The waitress was very patient and explained all our questions. We tried both meat & veg dishes both flavorful. I enjoyed the spicy ground beef (forgot the name). The injera (bread/utensil) was good texture and flavor, as well as never-ending servings. Very attentive waitress added to the positive vibe of Tadu.

Tiny space with colorful decor.

Great place for couples (first date or steady), meet with pals, or out-of-town guests. But note this place is tiny so not ideal for groups larger than 4.
author: McCracken C.

description: This place is AWESOME!!! Food was amazing. Staff were super friendly. A little on the small side but the food is exceptional.
author: Philip M.

description: There's a yummy Ethiopian food place nearby, hooray! We like to get the vegetarian platter and one of the meat options. Usually have left overs for the next day because portions are hearty. Nice folks run the place and they have entertaining music videos playing as you dine.
author: Chau N.

description:
I've lived in Ethiopia for two years and can be quite picky about Ethiopian food, but this place is pretty solid (compared to other restaurants in SF).

Definitely order the vegetarian fir fir (fir fir is injera with injera, such a weird concept, but seriously one of my favorite dishes!) - they mix in bell peppers, onions, and shiro giving it a nice and thick consistency. It could use a bit more kick (berbere) though!

Their vegetarian bayinet (or combo) was pretty standard, nothing too special.

Sambusas were good, but not very Ethiopian-esque. The outside was like wonton wrappers and it came with a Thai-inspired dipping sauce?

Anyway, I'd definitely come back for some firfir as this place has cheap and good eats!
author: Christina C.

description:
Note: This restaurant is in the SKETCHIEST part of SF. Tenderloin has time and time again been ranked #1 in SF for violent crime. 

That being said, the food here is AMAZING! I highly recommend the Veggie Combo!

The place is surprisingly perfectly clean despite the location, and the service is great. The staff is friendly and attentive, and even offers to refill your injera (Ethiopian bread) basket for FREE! 

Definitely worth the trip! Just be extra cautious at all times outside the restaurant, and travel there with a group :) Would not recommend venturing into this area at night.
author: Ju Ju H.

description: A bit crowded restaurant but it's acceptable. Food is great. I got Vegan Combo + Special Kitfo, Lamb and Beef Libs, and Sambussa. This meal was enough for four to five people. By the way, Injera has a little sour. Overall, five stars food.
author: Charles Z.

description:
Amazing food, great customer service.
Their waiter/cashier, Caleb has a nice, warm friendly smile and personality.
The menu with photos and pricing is on their website.

I ordered the Sambussa with beef appetizer, Lamb Tibs with Injera as the entrée, and Telba as a drink. 

The Sambussa is a crunchy, fried, meaty ball of deliciousness, kind of like a samosa (wait, is it a samosa?). They give you 3 nice triangles with a nice sauce to go with it (I wish they'd give more sauce, because it was very flavorful, lots of spices). 

The Lamb tibs is very delicious, served over a layer of Injera, with vegetables and tomatoes that give it a nice acidic flavor to the umami lamb. I recommend mixing everything together and use the Injera to grab the mixture, shove it in your mouth and lick your fingers. DO NOT TOUCH YOUR EYES!!! IT IS VERY FUCKING SPICY!!! 
Luckily for you, their sink is right outside their bathroom, so you can quickly wash your hands, blow your nose, and get right back to eating. Umm, on that note, be wary bringing a first time date here. 

I highly highly recommend ordering Telba, if you are ordering anything else, Telba is always the perfect compliment! Caleb, the super nice, friendly Ethiopian dude gave me some small sample of Telba and it was like sucking on the tit of Goddess (cause it comes with a straw). It tastes rather creamy with the texture of a basil seed drink and the flavor of a grounded cereal mix. I highly highly recommend ordering it, because it will help cool you down by counteracting the incredibly spicy food.

A couple of warnings: the food is very spicy, so don't touch your face. There are no utensils unless you ask (but please, just use your hands), and there is no parking, take the bus. 

Peace and godspeed.
author: Alan L.

description: Great food, great hosts!  If you're in the area and craving good Ethiopian food, you must check this one out.  It's not a fancy dine in place so get your expectations in order.  The place is small with limited seating, but the food is delicious.  I've been there a few times and haven't been disappointed even once.
author: Pavan G.

description: This is BY FAR the BEST Ethiopian food in the Bay, and as I love Ethiopian food, I've been to at least 7 or 8 in the area. Flavorful, delicious, absolutely delectable! If the food didn't speak for itself, the service is wonderful. It was my moms birthday and when they found out, they gave us appetizers and baklava on the house, and played an old Hindi happy birthday song over the speakers that she knew from her childhood; it made her day!
author: Prajakta J.

description: The food was excellent. We got the veggie combo and sambussa with lentil and it satisfied us both. We order some food to go too. Definitely will be back
author: Sophia K.

description:
Incredible. Neat. Authentic. Amazing. 

Small dining space but a refined and remodeled interior in an otherwise seedy part of town. Personal service and recommendation was great as well.
author: Michael B.

description: The food is so good and the owner is so nice. They always remember my order and a bunch of details about me. Overall the flavor is great and the service is good too. It is in the tenderloin so the ambiance is very causal but the pricing is reasonable as the entrees are $14 max. The portions are good and the injera bread is great as well. The food is just wonderful here. I really like their take out as well. I have brought a few friends over and now they all go there for food.
author: G L.

description: I've had vegetarian combos at Ethiopian restaurants all over the country. This was good but not exceptional. As usual, the red lentils were my favorite nice and spicy. Chickpeas were good. The potato chunks were a bit large and ungainly as well as kind of crunchy. But there was something nice and tasty served with the salad I'd never tasted before. I'd go there again even if the neighborhood is marginal.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
The place was really small -- just seven little tables for two people each, with random extra chairs here and there to squeeze in a third. Prepare for a moderate wait, especially since there only appears to be one waiter. However, that waiter was very friendly and fairly attentive, given that he had seven tables to deal with. 

But the main thing is the food. SO GOOD. The injera is perfect, not too moist and not too dry, and the vegetarian combo was pretty perfect (and a great value at around $12!). I really loved the vegetable medley, which consisted of mushrooms with bell peppers and onions in Ethiopian spices. I've never had a dish like that at an Ethiopian place before, and it was really tasty. Highly recommended!
author: Jen T.

description: Where do I even start. It's a vegan dream. Everything is amazing and very reasonably priced. I love Tadu!
author: Hannah Z.

description: Yes, yes yes yes yes!!! This small restaurant serves excellent food. We reserved a table and the owner even put a lovely "reserved" sign on it and greeted me with the most friendly of attitudes. The service was prompt and quick. Food was delivered hot and delicious and the vegetarian combo was soooo good. Sure, the neighborhood isn't the best. Saw a few people shooting up drugs on my way over from Civic Center, but Tadu is worth the trek. I would DEFINITELY come back. Thank you for everything, Tadu!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Delicious and different. Tadu purées a lot of their food so classics like lentils and yellow split peas are smoother than usual. I love Ethiopian food and appreciate that they are making it their own.

I had the veggie combo, which is affordable and delicious. The spices are balanced and the lentils, veggies, and beans are well-cooked. My favorite was the carrots and cabbage dish.

I had never had the puréed chick peas and puréed eggplant before. They are really good, basically a spicier version of hummus.

All in all, more than worth the trip to the Tenderloin.
author: Mel C.

description:
Servings here are generous. We ordered the vegetarian combination (great way to sample all of the vegetarian dishes instead of ordering just one), the chicken tibs, and the beef firfir. 

Tips:
If you like spicy - go with the Firfir (beef, not the lamb - they said they can't make the lamb as spicy). Got the chicken tibs as "spicy" as well but it definitely didn't have nearly as much kick as the beef firfir.
On wait times - came here on a Saturday night near closing time (8:40 pm) and they let us in (there was even a waiting line); pretty sure they kept letting people in around 9pm and maybe 10 minutes after.

All in all - the food was good but it wasn't mindblowingly better than Moya (I actually thought it was on par) so I think I'll stick with ordering from Moya and then eating at the City Beer Store (they let you bring food in) so that I can have delicious Ethiopian with delicious beer :).
author: Sylvia L.

description: Excellent Ethiopian food! It was served traditionally on injera, but you could order rice if you're gluten free, instead. Everything was wonderful!
author: Amy-Lee B.

description: I had the chance to try Tadu while visiting family in SF. My aunt referred me here and this was my first time I have ever tried Ethiopian food so I can't compare it to others but their dishes were really good and they offered lots of vegetarian options.
author: Cara W.

description: Can I say again how much I love places like this?  Small (5 tables?), cheap, informal, and homemade goodness.  Ethiopian food is fabulous, and this place does it really well.  Open kitchen with one woman at the stove and one dude working front of house.  My wife and I ordered a veg combo with an order of chicken tips.  It was all delicious, and we could barely finish it!  The bill came to just under 25 bucks for two.  It would have been more if they had a liquor license!   Really gracious service.   This has become our "go-to" place in San Francisco for Ethiopian food.
author: Robert B.

description:
Eating at Tadu feels like eating at your aunt's house. The tiny seating area was full of people and the bright colors and art were welcoming. It really is tiny, but it's clean and brightly lit so I didn't mind being so close to the other tables. 

We got lamb tibs ($12.95) which were a little dry but the onions and rosemary flavoring was so good we devoured it. We got the kitfo (12.95) which was buttery and had a strong umami flavor. I would recommend it if you really love meat. We also got the cabbage (9.95) , which could have used some salt but was a great balance to the lamb and beef. 

The owner came around a couple of times to make sure we were comfortable which I always appreciate. 

9/10 food
9/10 ambience and noise level
10/10 service and pricing
author: Mayhah S.

description:
I rarely give 5 star reviews on a first visit, but felt compelled to do so for Tadu. Right off the bat we were greeted and offered a seat. Throughout the visit there were friendly vibes all around.

The veggie combo and chicken tibs were plenty of food for two guys who just rode 18 miles on bike and ran another 4 miles. Highly recommend the drink, "telba"--roasted then ground flax seeds in water and sweetened with honey. Very refreshing.

Really hope that Tadu thrives in the neighborhood. I managed to get a couple looking through the window to come in after I gave them the "two thumbs up" gesture! Will be back with friends.
author: Christopher W.

description:
I'm definitely going to be frequenting this restaurant after my first visit tonight.

I've always been a huge fan of Ethiopian cuisine, with New Eritrea being one of my favorite SF spots. The only drawback about New Eritrea is that it's all the way in the Sunset, which isn't very conveniently located for me (but they're still worth the drive)!

But I digress. I was so glad the girlfriend found this spot on Yelp that was so close to where we work and on our way home. When we first walked it, it appears to be completely full, all tables occupied. The sweet owner asked us if we wanted to dine in and pulled out an extra table that fit perfectly in the little nook of space left in the room.

We ordered the Special Kitfo (medium rare), The beef Tibs, and the vegetarian combination. Despite there only being two employees running the show,  the chef and the server, our meal came out with hardly a wait and everything was delicious! If I had to pick a favorite dish, it'd probably have to be the Kitfo Special. But the beef Tibs was a very close runner up.

If you're on the fence about this place, jump off already! There's a reason they have such high ratings. Great service & amazing food. Let the food speak for itself. :)
author: Jenny F.

description: Visited because of the high yelp ratings. Also came specifically for the vegan options and had the vegetarian combo. Quite frankly the food  while not bad was not tasty either. I think overall it's par for the course. I won't return but was it was worth trying since I hadn't been before
author: Will W.

description:
Yelp suggested this restaurant to me because I was in the neighborhood and I'm glad it did! Such delicious food. we had the veggie combo, lamb nibs and a beef kifta (sp?) all were so delicious. The owner also provided great service. We need more places like this in the tenderloin!

Also the place doesn't sell alcohol but is fine with BYOB
author: Lisa B.

description: great hole-in-the-wall ethiopian food! their hot sauce is actually spicy and their injera bread is so tangy and delicious. i also tried the ethiopian tea, which one of the staff people described as spicy, but it wasn't...really....anyway, the place really is small, i think about 4 tables with 4 seats each, so don't plan on being able to sit in and eat during busy times. definitely a good value for what you pay and an interesting meal to have during the week. also: you will have #injerabelly aftewards :)
author: Meryam B.

description: Nice and tasty food. This is such a small Ethiopian place with a numerous options for vegetarians! Injera was soft with a light sour taste. Had been there with a small group and the place was tight with no room for air. Service was not commendable. If you are there only for the food then you would enjoy it! Would highly recommend shiro wot and mushroom/brinjal gravy for injera.
author: Sukirti S.

description:
Amazing food and extremely friendly staff and owner.

Try the tips and veg sampler!!!
author: Adam D.

description:
I was searching for a gluten free restaurant in the tenderloin and this one kept coming up as the top one (gf or regular), so I thought fate must want me to go. I was not disappointed!

It feels like a little while in the wall (maybe 4 small tables total) with Ethiopian art in the wall. The food was delicious and came very quickly! I ordered the lamb tibs with greens (which they gave to me for free) and the gluten free injera ($3 more). It was all so flavorful and not too spicy (they can add spice if you want). I couldn't finish it in one sitting and gladly took leftovers for later. 

This place is a gem!
author: Kevin M.

description:
I came here on a Monday evening around 8pm with a few friends. While seating is rather sparse, especially for groups larger than two, plenty of seats were available when we walked in.

We had the beef sambussa to start, and the lamb and beef tibs with injera as entrees. 
The sambussa was a dumpling-like appetizer, with juicy, slightly spicy ground beef wrapped in a perfectly crunchy and flaky shell of dough, and accompanied with a orange dipping sauce which added a ton of seasoning without overpowering the taste of the wrapping or the beef. 

The injera was just as it should be, soft and spongy, without being overpowering or too sour. I absolutely recommend the lamb tibs -- tender lamb cubes sautéed with the most delicious caramelized onions, and seasoned heavily with black pepper and not much else. While not readily apparently after the first few bites, the lamb tibs are actually low-key spicy, and will definitely warm you up after a while. 

It's not the best Ethiopian food I've ever had, but it's definitely up there.
author: Caleb W.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city.  Take a group of friends and share something like the lamb tibs, vegetarian combo, and the vegetable melody dish.  Also try some of their coffee, which is ground right there for individual cups so it is very smooth.  

Going to the area is always an adventure because this is in the Tenderloin, but don't let that deter you.  The owner is very friendly and even gave a sample of another dish to try.
author: Peter M.

description: Just went here for our four year anniversary. We had Ethiopian on our first date four years ago from today, so it's become tradition to explore Ethiopian places on our anniversary. This place was definitely a good find- quaint and SO absolutely delicious. What a great meal and sweet, attentive staff. We will be back!
author: Keri M.

description:
Had a craving for Ethiopian and decided to brave Ellis street to have it after reading the rave reviews. We arrived to a packed restaurant (dinner rush around 8pm on a Tuesday) and had to wait about 30 minutes for a table. This was no bother as it gave time to decide what to order and to admire the food that everyone else had ordered. 

The owner was very generous and about 15 minutes into our wait, brought over a complimentary appetizer to tide us over. Prior to seating us, he came back to take our order, perfectly timed since once our table became available and our drinks were poured, our hot food arrived. 

We ordered the veggie combo and the lamb tibs. The food was flavorful and juicy, the injera light and fluffy.

As we leaned back in our chairs stuffed to the brim, the owner once again surprised us by bringing complimentary baklava to our table for dessert.

Overall, it was a very nice experience. The food was tasty and reasonably priced. The icing on the cake was that the owner went out of his way to ensure we were taken care of, which was over and above our expectations.
author: Rach D.

description: Very good food and a very good value.  Staff is very friendly and helpful.  It's a small, cozy place.  We will definitely come back and recommend to friends.
author: Peter V.

description:
Order- veggie combo. 

Taste- Great, yummmm. Loved their chickpeas. 

Service- Slow but friendly.

Cost- Reasonable. Costed me $ 12.

Do not miss this.
author: Dee S.

description:
Whoooooaaaaaaa. This? Was the best meal I've had in a long time. We had the special kitfo and lamb tibs. I had come with high hopes after reading a lot of good things about Tadu, and it far exceeded my expectations. We finished the meal with baklava which was also excellent. 

The staff is also really, really nice. I hope these guys succeed and stick around a long time.
author: Erin B.

description:
My boyfriend and I live in the area and wanted to try this new hole in the wall, and what a wonderful experience!!!!

We shared the vegetarian platter, which was a perfect amount of food for two people who aren't starving hungry. That, plus a baklava dessert, was just right (but I wish I could have tried more!)

What we loved more than all else was the service 
- the staff were so kind, attentive, and gracious. We felt appreciated as diners, a lovely and rare feeling these days.
author: Celina T.

description:
So freaaaaaaking delicious. I've only just started trying Ethiopian food, and let me just say, if you haven't tried it you're missing out. Had the chicken tibs with injera and the ritko sandwich. The ayub cheese will change your life. Don't forget to finish off with some Ethiopian coffee (seriously, the best coffee, and starting to be come my absolute favorite).

Great service and great food. Will be back again!
author: Alyson S.

description: The beef tips was very delicious. The restaurant was so small and you have to wait until finding available space, but it is worth to wait if you like Ethiopian food! Service was so friendly as well
author: Irfan K.

description: I am in from the east coast and never tied  Ethiopian food before and thought to try this while in SF.  In a word OUTSTANDING,  if you are in San Fran it is a must try and the great staff will recommend some great options.
author: Chris B.

description:
I had read a lot about this place on Yelp and have seen in consistently rated in the Top 10 SFO restaurants. This was my first experience with Ethiopian food and needless to say, I absolutely loved it. Ordered a Vegetarian combination and Chicken Tibs. Really loved the Misir Wot and Shiro Wot . The rest of the lentils and salads were alright. 

Cons: It is located in the Tenderloin area, which is a sketchy neighbourhood. Also, I wish the Injera were served hot.

Mentioned the cons to the owner and he took my review positively. Overall, anyone in SFO city should check out this place.
author: Pranav B.

description: Best Ethiopian I have had in a while! Reasonable prices and friendly staff.  Good thing I live nearby, because I will definitely be back for more.
author: Ernesto M.

description: This place is tiny, but packed. I believe the one guy serving is new, and isn't very helpful. You can tell he's all over the place. He didn't give my options for bread, and didn't give myself of people their water. Other people had to walk up to him just to get service. He keeps standing around with the deer in a headlight look. The hygiene here is questionable as I can see their meat grinder sitting next to the sink, and saw them handling credit cards then going straight to peeping food without washing their hands. The people next to me found a piece of METAL in their food! I also never got part of my order. As for the food I did get, it was mediocre at best.
author: Wang C.

description: I love Ethiopian food and this place offered great food and friendly service. The place was clean, too. I would recommend it to any of my friends looking for Ethiopian food.
author: Brian P.

description:
What an exiting experience.  I know the owner and I am proud of him. Food is great
And I come back again and again for the Gluten free Injera from home. I had to share this with you all.
author: Getachew A.

description: Super delicious Ethiopian food. Loved the sambusas and beef and chicken tibs. Everything tasted super fresh and was visually appealing, which can be difficult with lentils and such. Very nice owner and staff as well.
author: Rowena L.

description: The food was absolutely fantastic. Best Ethiopian I've had so far! Service was also excellent. The owner was there and he was keeping an eye on all the tables in case they needed something. We had the lamb tibs and the kitfo. Also had the timatim fit fit which was a great surprise. Love it
author: Laura D.

description: I have eaten at a few Ethiopian restaurants in so cal especially in the Fairfax district where Little Ethiopia is but this restaurant beats any of them. That's because the owners are in the restaurant cooking and taking care of the customers and making sure everyone likes the food. It had a home made feel to it and our server made some good recommendations for us. Only downside is the neighborhood with some shady characters all around but the restaurant itself is amazing and a must try. We got the vegetarian combo with an extra side order of the shiro wat which was really good. The spicy powder they give is the bomb!
author: Kishore K.

description:
Overall
Ethiopian vegan food that tastes amazing which it fills me 120% at a great price, served by super nice people who help you out indefinitely. Side note... Suffers of trypophobia be warned

Food
As a Ethiopian food lover its hard for me to deny the food. Delicious vegan plates and quite a number of vegan choices. And I cant stress any more that it is soooooo filling. For the price I would eat here all the time.

Service
Really good service. Everyone was very helpful and patient. A very friendly bunch of people who are involved with your orders and service. A family and friend environment.
author: K. K.

description:
This place was the highlight of our trip to San Francisco.  Yes, it is in a bad neighborhood, but no one yelled at us or anything.  

The place is tiny.  Only a couple of tables.  The server might have been the nicest person we encountered on our whole trip.  He was so patient with our questions, and recommended the lamb dibs, which was one of the most delicious things I've ever had.  

I doubt I'll visit SF again, but if I do, this is my go-to!
author: Evan J.

description: This CRAZY AUTHENTIC ETHIOPIAN just in the middle of the city will make you wanna go to Africa! It's cheap, people are friendly and it's super tasty! Totally would recommend the vegetarian melody to share even for 2 people and you will not regret it!
author: Irina P.

description:
This is the best Ethiopian food in the east bay by far.I have been to all Ethiopian restaurant in the bay area I will give 5 star for concintancy 
Keep it up I will definitely go back to Tadu
author: Messai M.

description: A friend took me to lunch here today.  I was not expecting such a clean well run eatery.  The staff were very polite and able to recommend an excellent lunch choice.  We split a combination place with chicken sauted with onions.  It was delicious and filling and shock of shocks, very reasonably priced!  I will definitely return.  I left one of my phones on the table and the proprietor ran all the way down the block to give it to me.  Kudos!
author: Michael W.

description:
The food was very good - 

The inexperienced waiter seemed very forgetful and was having a tough time with all tables going at once.
author: okie r.

description: Ethiopian food.. Im trying for the first time. Me and my buddy went to the place. Nice service. Not a big dine in...neighbourhood wasnt great... but the food was good.. we ordered veg combo wand chicken tibs... I liked the chicken tibs more. my buddy was vegetarian ... he had the veg combo and was little bit bland .. if it was spicy would have been much better
author: Pavan N.

description:
Flavorful and tasty food. Their dry spicy powder adds nice ting to the food. 
Ignore the neighborhood surroundings.. This small place can't be skipped
author: Mansi B.

description:
Cute little, authentic place in the tenderloin. Veggie combo, sambusas and shiro wereabsolutely fantastic! Highly recommend (especially for vegetarians). 

Service was excellent. Owner was there and suggested us to get the shiro instead of two veggie combos which turned out to be a great call. Also through in a baklava when we decided to get one after paying the bill. Will definitely be back soon! Best Ethiopian I have found in the city...
author: Rishee J.

description:
This was my first time having Ethiopian food and I loved it! My mom and I are vegetarian and there were a ton of vegetarian options!! Our host was amazing, he recommended the veggie combo, and we thoroughly enjoyed it. The area around the restaurant (Ellis Street or something), was a bit sketch, but the restaurants aura was really upbeat and comfortable. 

If you want really good food and amazing service go here!!
author: Shruti M.

description: This is very good Ethiopian food and the staff is very friendly and accommodating. The beef Tibs has great flavor and is a safe bet for anyone who has never eaten Ethiopian food before. The Sambussa appetizer with beef is also good.
author: Marc P.

description:
Tadu is quaint restaurant located close to the Financial district. The neighborhood itself is a little sketchy, but not as bad as some spots in the tenderloin area. It can only seat about 20 people at a time, so be prepared to wait at least 15-20 minutes to land a table.

The food is all sorts of awesome. Lamb tibs, combo plates, the kifto sandwich are all very flavorful and contain the right blend of spices. 

If you've never had Ethiopian food before, it is very similar to Indian in terms of the ingredients, spices and flavor. This place definitely hits the spot.

Definitely a must visit.
author: Ganesh I.

description: amazing food! really amazing flavors that really pop in your mouth. the sambosas were extremely fluffy and crunchy at the same time. the food had this beautiful spice to it that wasn't a chile spice, but i'm still trying to figure out what it was
author: Xavier L.

description: Great service,  delicious food and a stellar deal.   I took a friend here who never tried Ethiopian food before and he was blown away (they have a new loyal customer).   They seated us quickly on  Friday night.   Even when I came with a large group before,  the staff was very accommodating and served us quickly.   They're quick,  efficient,  friendly and you can see how clean the kitchen is by watching them work. A+ rating.
author: Michelle W.

description: Authentic Ethiopian food with great service!!! The kito was excellent along with the sides!
author: Feven T.

description: A solid 5-star experience. The best Ethiopian food that I've ever had. We ordered the lamb tibs, the special kitfo, and the veggie special. The lamb and the kitfo were great, but the veggies were off the chart delicious. The injeera was perfect. Slightly sour, light, and spongy. The service was perfect. Our waiter was helpful, attentive, friendly, and let us know that we could buy honey wine from across the street at Red Sea Grocery to have with our dinner. Highly recommended. We will be back!
author: Da Wei S.

description:
I have had Ethiopian a couple of times at other places and found this food to be exceptional for the price. My gf is new to the food and she found it fantastic. 

Ellis street is not a great street but once inside the contemperary clean and quiet restaurant you will forget about the TL. 

The wait staff helped us order and the food tasted great.
author: Andre M.

description: Incredible food and friendly environment. Loved how spicy everything is, would absolutely come back.
author: Rose D.

description:
Wow!  This place is great!  The food is all fresh, made to order and perfectly spiced.  The couple who works there (owners I presume) are warm, friendly gentle people who obviously take great pride in every aspect of the place.  The Tenderloin has quite a few mom and pop ethic places but the quality varies.  It's nice to see this one at the top of its game.  

Don't be put off by the neighborhood.  Yes, there are random people roaming the streets and some semi-covert drug use but it's infrequently seen and nothing is threatening about it all.....a mild part of the colorful vibrant Tenderloin.   In fact, it's just a couple blocks off Union Sq. among other nice places.  

Go for the authentic experience.....a dying breed in our city as high rents continue to push gems like this out.  Support it.  Go in person.  Have it delivered.  Order and pick up.  Lots of ways to enjoy a very satisfying, solid Ethiopian meal.
author: John B.

description: 5 stars, really? I wish, I'd love a good Ethiopian restaurant this side of the bay, but not the night we were there. The veggie combo was okay, but the lamb tibs were and chewy. Sooo unappetizing. :(
author: Sarah G.

description: A Tenderloin gem if there ever was one. Amazing Ethiopian cuisine in an intimate setting. Worth the walk through sketchyville. A must try. Will be back.
author: Alex W.

description: This is a sweet little place, although right on the edge of the Tenderloin.  The food is just awesome!  I love the powerfully delicious and savory flavors.  Great, great vegan selections.   It's inexpensive.  Portions are generous.  The staff is a pleasure to work with.  Love them.
author: Jim L.

description:
Great food, helpful service and a friendly atmosphere. What more could you ask for?

Lamb tibs is the priciest order on the menu (~$14.00) yet it was so filling and exquisitely seasoned that I definitely recommend.
author: L M.

description:
Found Tadu by chance as I was walking home, stopped to chat to the friendly owner and came back for food an hour later. I'm so excited to have a good Ethipian restaurant in my neighborhood. 

I had the vegetarian combo, it came with the lightest and fluffiest injera I've tasted. Each dish was excellent, the Kik Alicha and Azifa especially stood out.

I'll definitely be back. Often.
author: Amanda S.

description:
I've eaten at all of the Ethiopian places in the city and this is by far my favorite so far. 

You can even see them grinding the fresh meat in the back. I definitely encourage you to try the kitfo rare - you're in for a treat.
author: Kory-Oren E.

description: Very good food and great service. Highly recommend this place. They don't skimp on the injera bread and refill the tea as well.
author: Sandeep A.

description:
I have been here twice this week for takeout, and sketchy neighborhood be damned, I'll be back for more!  

On my first visit, my order, the vegetarian combination, consists of about 7 different vegetarian dishes that they offer, so one gets a true sample of their menu.  And, this dish just blew me away!  There was such a variety of flavors, one more amazing than the next!  On my next visit, I ordered the lamb tibs, lamb ribs and meat pieces with onions that are cooked firm, slightly chewy and fully flavored. When I asked to have a vegetable stew (wot) that I had enjoyed so much with the lamb, instead of having me order it as a separate side, the kind woman who was helping me suggested that she would just include it on my lamb dish for an extra $1!!  That was just the perfect amount for me and I really appreciated her accommodating my wish.  So, what more can I add?!!  Go and try it!
author: Yvette F.

description:
I'll be honest... I've never had Ethiopian food in my life.  It's been something that I've been meaning to try for several years.  The only thing I've heard has been from my a family member in DC who has told me negative things about his multiple experiences.  But, I still wanted to try it and check it off my list for myself.

With that being said, I'm so glad this was my first experience.  The staff was attentive friendly and attentive, the food was superb, and the meal was an excellent value (Combo Veggie Platter).  It's a new restaurant that will definitely be a longterm gem of the city if it maintains these standards.  I will be back!  Thanks Tadu!
author: Darius Y.

description: This is my family's favorite restaurant. So much so that my son thinks it should get 10 stars. The menu, the service, the warmth of the host is all unparalleled. I've had Ethiopian food but never this good. Every dish on the menu is delicious. Our favorite is Kitfo and Beef Berbere. Can't recommend it enough!!
author: Ashima S.

description: Best food Ethiopian food I have ever had. Went tonight with two of my friends. The waiter was extremely helpful and so very nice. For an appetizer we had the lentil sambussa which was so moist and delicious. For dinner I had the lamb tibs, one friend had the special kitfo and my other friend has the vegetarian combination. We all thought it was absolutely delicious. Then for dessert we had the baklava. Probably the best that I have ever had. Will definitely go back. Thank you Tadu!
author: Brianna M.

description: Amazing! We ordered the lamb and chicken entrees on injera and the veggie combo. Fed 7 of us to complete content. The lamb was spicy but balanced by the caramelized onions.
author: Thomas K.

description: Rainy Friday, decided to try other non typical food out there. Ethiopian food came to mind and found this new cosy place. Really liked the atmosphere here. Friendly staff and great service. It was a quiet night. They kept on coming to our table to check if we were happy with everything. Had ground beef sambussa for appetizers. Then we ordered lamp and beef tibs. For beginner you eat with your hands. No utensils if you wanna do it right. Love the flavors and spices they use, bring back memories of my travel to Africa. Interesting sponge bread made of teff flour (wheat) used to wrap the meat and veggies. The pepper powder is super spicy! Be careful a dash can set you on fire and make you go running for more water. I would definitely come back and try more dishes. The food is not something I eat everyday. I'm glad that I found this new gem for Ethiopian cuisine.
author: Hua T.

description: Wonderful traditional Ethiopian food!!! Four of us shared the vegetarian combo, sambussa, and buticha salad and extra injera it was so good!!!! Lots of verity and helpful staff. Good prices and lots of food! Very clean facility including the bathroom
author: Jessica S.

description: A wonderful find!  A surprising little "hole in the wall" in the Tenderloin.  Just a handful of tables, but worth seeking out (and waiting, if you must).
author: Matt W.

description: Delicious!  It was a ton of food but every bite was amazing. The service was great too. It's a cute, clean spot. Will go back in a heartbeat.
author: Kat R.

description: Tried the lentil Sambussa appetizer and it was GREAT! definitely get the veggie combo if you want a true mix of Ethiopian flavor. Additionally, the Kitfo is fantastic! The mix of spices and flavors are perfect.
author: Danielle J.

description: Starving like Marvin we came in here based on Yelp. Ordered the veggie combo dish and the chicken ribs... Couldn't stop eating!excellent friendly service, delicious food, very reasonable prices. Can byob with no corkage fee.
author: Maureen P.

description: Food, mix of spices, and proprietors were spectacular! If you enjoy spicy, ask for that. If you want mild, always an option. The bread is imported from Ethiopia, something unique you must try!  I'm going back and will bring friends!
author: Ginny K.

description:
I don't eat meat, so I got the vegetarian combo. It was so delicious and filling! I eat a lot and I was worried it wouldn't fill me up, but it sure did! 

Staff extremely nice and truly wants you to have a good time! Will def go back!
author: Evgeniy C.

description:
This place is out of control good. I've been here twice and both times it was heaven. One order of sambussas and one veggie combo will make a filling meal for two vegetarians. If you're really hungry, order two of the vegetarian dishes. You can have them served together on one big injera so you can share. 

My favorite of the vegetarian dishes is the Shiro Wot. The Misir Wot is a close second. I like spicy food though. If you don't, you might like the Kik Alicha Wot better. 

As a bonus - the owner is really welcoming and clearly excited about the food.
author: Katy H.

description: Very busy with very limited seating, therefore ordered to go. Food was delicious and spicy. Both cook and girl taking the order were very nice. Only thing I wish was they had photos of the food so I could have an idea what I was ordering. My Sambussa was delicious!!!
author: Sharmi D.

description:
All food are soooooo delicious and their service is great!!!
I love Sambussa, Misir Wot and The Vegetable Melody.

I come here two or three times a month:))
author: Iguanatte S.

description: I wish I could rate 5 plus star here.....  The Food has unique flavor, authentic. Served with warm welcome & passion.....
author: Omkar P.

description:
Been here twice for Ethiopian in the last week and the food is awesome! Try the chicken tibs! Customer service is pretty good - the first time I was there, they even served complimentary dessert! 

The prices are very reasonable and both times we had some leftovers. Take them in a box even if you don't need them - instead give them to one of the homeless folks on the street outside.
author: Rohit B.

description: This place is great! I've had Ethiopian food once before in Calgary and it didn't compare at all to Tadu. I had the vegetarian combo plate and my hubby had the Kifto. Both were really good and the injera was so soft! Elias took our order and we chatted with him a bit afterwards about the food. Really nice guy! He made us feel super welcome.
author: Jennifer P.

description: When a restaurant offers you consistently delicious food and convivial service for over a year and half, you can't help but to give it a high-five-stars. Go Tadu!
author: Misikir T.

description: I really enjoyed the vegetable combination.
author: John W.

description: Sometimes the small and simple places are where you find the tastiest food and courteous staff. This is one of those gems. Highly recommend the veggie combo platter
author: Raja B.

description: Best Ethiopian I've had. Mom and Pop owners are really nice. Definitely one of my favorite low cost spots to eat.
author: Martin M.

description: Very good Ethiopian food - I'll be back despite it not being that accessible neighborhood wise for me. Appreciate their willingness to cook for restrictioms, and they have GF injera. Also, super friendly staff! Yum
author: Sarah X.

description: Great place for great value. The neighborhood is sketchy just as one would expect for tenderloin, but food is amazing. We had the ribs, veggie combo and shiro wot. Thumbs up
author: Stasiek Ś.

description:
Kifto is really great! The service is fast and nice. Only downside is that you have to walk through the sketchy neighborhood. But the restaurant is really clean.

Don't forget to order kifto as medium rare. If it's cooked too much, it loses that awesomeness.
author: Ryosuke K.

description: This is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant. And I've been to a considerable amount of Ethiopian restaurants around the country. If you don't try this place, you are leading an inadequate life.
author: Hunter S.

description:
I have been meaning to write a review for this place since I went with my sister back in November. Yes, it's in a sketchy area of the tenderloin, however the restaurant is part of a movement to make the area safe and taking an uber, taxi or lyft, you can avoid the more questionable surrounding streets.

We came around 530pm and it was already packedm this is a very small place and the wait for takeout was 20minutes so we figured tables would free up in that time anyway. The owner went out of his way to accommodate both us and the party behind us, adding two extra tables and apologizing profusely for us having waited outside. Food is huge portions and really well spiced. We had the veg platter which I recommend because you taste evrything as well as the lamb tibs. There is a ton of meat, they really dont skimp on it and the flavours are good. We also ordered some samosa like appetizer which was good and came with a sort of chutney sauce. The owner actually comped us the appetizer which was totally unexpected but really nice of him. It looks like a family run business and service was great, water was refilled and unlimited spongy bread to go with our meal. Prices are super reasonable. I would highly recommend this place as one of the best ethiopian places in the Bay Area. My sister had never had ethiopian before but I think shes been converted after dining here.
author: Lindsay D.

description:
Really impressed and very happy this restaurant is in my neighborhood!  The service was wonderful. the women and the owner were very hospitable, made great suggestions and service was very fast.  The space is very clean and inviting, although a little small,  but very cozy.  Great colors and accents.  They were very curious about our prior experience with Ethiopian food and how we would compare them to other restaurants.  Seemed very open to feedback as well which shows they really want to succeed.  

Came here last night with my partner and friends and we were all very pleased with our meal.  I think the prices were very reasonable for the quantity and quality of food we received.  We ordered the vegetarian combo and the lamb tibs which were all delicious.  The flavors and spices were excellent.  I will definitely be going back soon!
author: Alexandria S.

description: This place has delicious food! Definitely in a shady part of town, so if you're wanting to walk there - don't. Definitely Uber! But for the price and for the quality of food it is definitely worth it!
author: Jenni B.

description:
If you are looking for fancy this is not your place, it's the food you come here for.
Small place, accommodating host and good food.  We got the vegetarian combo platter and lamb tibits and it was all good, the collard greens were exceptional!  The eve I was there the ex-ambassador to Ethiopia was eating these with a group of 18. 
It you want beer the store across the street sells chilled single bottle.
author: Daljit S.

description: In the heart of the Tenderloin, we didn't expect such a wonderful restaurant! It's not fancy, but very clean, and the food looks and tastes amazingly fresh and flavorful. You can tell the owners really care about what they serve, and we LOVED it. So good! We will be back often. Thank you!
author: Nathalie F.

description: The food was delicious!   We ordered the vegetarian combo and the lamb tibs for two people.  We loved the variety of the veggie combo  which comes with 5 different items and the lamb tibs is so flavorful with two sprigs of rosemary right in our dish.   The restaurant is small but the food comes out fast.  I will be back when  I have my Ethiopian food craving again!
author: Amy C.

description: Small, but full of love. I haven't had a meal this full of passion in a long long time.
author: Robert S.

description: Best Ethiopian food I've had. Their lentil and chick pea dishes are so flavorful, and the sauce that comes with the beef sambusa was so good that we used the leftover sauce on all our extra injera. Service was quick and they couldn't have been friendlier or more welcoming. If you have reservations about going to the Tenderloin, it's time you got over them because this place is awesome.
author: Rebecca R.

description: Cute little hole in the wall spot.  Awesome food.  We had a Veggie Combo plate and Veggie Sambussas for an appetizer.  The Sambussas were so yummy, we had to order another one.  We were hoping for a glass of honey wine, but they don't have a liquor license.  However, you're free to bring you're own drinks if you like.
author: Frisco T.

description: Had lamb tibs and veggie combo , all excellent , nice and clean place, menu is a little hard to read if your not familiar with the cuisine, but owner was kind and ready to explain
author: Ben K.

description: This place is delicious, very clean, and top food value for your money.  Do visit.  Come hungry.  Would eat everyday.  9.5/10 (lost half marks because their chairs can be kinda uncomfortable)
author: Nick C.

description: Yummy food. Ordered the vegetarian platter. It was great. Small space but still comfy.
author: Sarah D.

description: Bottom line: Tadu is delicious, reasonable, and has great service. I love good Ethiopian food and the only other place I've tried so far in SF is Massawa but we were disappointed-it was a bit overpriced for small portions and they limit injera. For anyone that is new to it, I recommend getting a combo platter (my only gripe is that Tadu does a veggie combo but not a meat one). We got a veggie platter and added a meat tibs, the flaxseed drink was very good as well. Seating is pretty limited but the restaurant is clean and bright.
author: Amber F.

description: This is a quaint place. Don't be dissuaded by the walk through the Tenderloin, this place is the real deal and the food is great! The lamb tibs and the vegetarian combo were delicious. It was a lot of food for two people.  Have it with the injera.
author: David B.

description:
